13289705.review:
Every now and then I find a game that is entirely mediocre in every way, and I have a hard time with my overall recommendation of it. Papo & Yo fits squarely into this category – it’s never bad, but it’s never more than simply okay either.
 
For positives, I can easily say that Papo & Yo is a very pleasing game, visually. You spend the majority of your game time in a favela in Brazil, solving Alice in Wonderland-esque puzzles with floating platforms and clever mechanics which change your landscape in interesting ways. It doesn’t take very long to progress through, and feels mostly tight with controls and camera movements.
 
However, there seems to be just a layer of polish in all aspects that prevents this game from being better than average. The animations are choppy, and some game mechanics, such as jumping puzzles, may not feel as accurate as other platforming games.
 
The story is my main dividing point. Although the narrative is essentially a very dark memoir, everything that you really need to know about the tale is shown to you up front. When the curtains are pulled back for a big reveal, you are basically shown what you’ve known since booting up the game – the monster is your father, and the poisonous frogs that put him into an uncontrollable rage are bottles of alcohol. It almost seemed odd that they decided to spend so much time at the end of the game devoted to showing you this, as that is the outset of the game.
 
To be fair, Papo & Yo has its heart in the right place, it just could have used a little more time to shine up what’s already there. However, this game is entirely skippable. Not recommended, unless you can find it as part of a package deal or it’s on a steep sale.

13280996.review: I was hesitant about this game (especially because I didn't like the title), but I was pleasantly surprised. This is a very personal and emotional story told by the Director/Writer through the game about what appears to be a romanticised and fantastical recount of his childhood memories of his abusive, alcoholic father. The game deals with the trauma of these memories tastefully in a very unique, visually appealing world. The trailer shows you honestly what the gameplay is like; third person puzzle solving. The puzzles are very intuitive and accessible, and this game could be played comfortably by a young kid (who may well be the target audience). I really liked the production design, soundtrack and atmosphere of the game; it's a good little story with entertaining gameplay that doesn't punish you relentlessly (like LIMBO). *****

13154214.review:
This game is, in a word, stunning.

Since I opened Papo & Yo, I've been admittedly obsessed. The way that the developers (Minority) managed to tie in mature and serious themes like alcoholism and domestic violence without using gratuitous violence or gore is commendable. In fact, Papo & Yo doesn't contain any gore at all! The story is truly captivating and you find yourself getting increasingly attached to the characters as time goes on, despite the minimal use of dialogue.

The gameplay itself is mainly a mix of casual puzzles and platforming. It's a simplistic way of bolstering the narrative, and was implemented amazingly. There are only a few achievements, but I had a lot of fun getting them all. A second playthrough of the game allows for collecting hats (which appear on dolls seen throughout the game).

I'm not one for writing serious reviews, but this game is deserving of nothing short of a proper review. Completing this game felt like a spiritual experience, and I'll be sure to do it again soon. Whatever the price is for this game right now, it's worth every penny.

13133680.review: Papo and Yo is not a game that I usually play; I hate platformers and I'm not that patient with puzzle games. However, Papo and Yo ranks among the most deep, memorable, and compelling games I've ever played.  Papo and Yo utilizes gameplay and storytelling to craft a moving tale about struggle, abuse, and acceptance. Your journey with Papo paints a complex, loving, and brutal picture of a son's relaitonship with his abusive father. This game's use of allegory is unparalleled in the gaming industry. If you're looking for a game with compelling gameplay and intent, play Papo and Yo. Warning; you might cry at the end. I kind of did.

13104222.review:
I'm an hour into the game so far. 

I quite like it. The music is great, the art design is wonderful, whimsical and fun. Has a mysterious sort of feel that is at the same time, fun and haunting. I found my first play feeling a bit of trepidation.  The opening has the creator thank those around him while growing up for helping him live through his childhood.  

It's fantastic what this game is doing. It is enabling someone to share an important narrative that is often unheard. Not only through story, spoken or written words but in gameplay. Gameplay serves to communicate the feeling of fear, excitement, paranoia and hope. 

This is an accurate portrayal of one persons difficult childood, dealing with abuse and loss. This game rings true and accurate with my own as well. I highly recommend this game to anyone who is curious what it might be like to be scared when a parent gets home. I recommend this game to people who enjoy puzzles and platformers that may be a bit on the simple side but serve to communicate something greater. I recommend this game to people who want more heart and sincerity in their game and less brown, gray and repetitive shooting. I recommend this game to people who want to feel emotions while they play a game.

Uma aventura breve, mas incrível. Todos os elementos são muito bem interligados e o resultado é surpreendente, fazendo com que fique por um bom tempo na lembrança por mais que não tenha um bom fator replay. Recomendado para quando se estiver buscando algo novo e diferente entre um título AAA e outro.

PRÓS
+ Estética incomparável gera sorrisos de orelha a orelha em cada detalhe
+ Trilha e efeitos sonoros muito bem produzidos colaboram muito para a atmosfera do jogo
+ A abordagem lúdica e poética gera reflexão para o pesado tema da narrativa, carregando a imaginação do protagonista para o jogador
+  Jogabilidade simples e responsiva que raramente se põe entre o jogador e seu objetivo lembra os jogos de plataforma 3D mais tradicionais

CONTRAS
- Enigmas fáceis fazem com que o jogo seja relaxante, mas pouco desafiador
- Campanha linear e relativamente curta, com fator replay quase nulo
- Pouca variedade de desafios faz do jogo levemente enjoativo (nada grave considerando sua duração)

12857178.review:
I don't like platformer.  I don't like jumping puzzles.  I especially don't like timing puzzles.  I'm not very good at any of those.  Because of that, I should not have liked this game.  But I did.  I liked this game a lot.

The gameplay was simple enough that I could play through it without getting seriously frustrated by my lack of skill; but still challenging enough not to be boring.   The puzzles that did not involve jumping and timing were very clever, but for the most part still logical and intuitive once you got into the flow of the game.  There were a few odd moments where the puzzles did not make a whole lot of sense, and I was force to rely on a walkthrough; but very few (unlike so many modern puzzle games, where randomness is used as a cheap and easy substitute for cleverness).  The mechanics of the game are very entertaining in themselves, particularly once Lulu is introduced.

The game design is beautiful; and the creators use of an uncommon setting was brilliant.  The third-world backdrop meshed very well with the fantastical elements; creating a seamless world with it's own unique and readily-identifiable logic.  The artwork is stunning, and the inclusion of works by actual environmental artists nothing short of amazing.  The similar use of third-world characters, rather than white Europeans or stereotypical fantasy creatures is similarly inspiring.  The music is beautiful, and in spots almost breathtaking, wonderfully blending traditional and orchestral sounds.  Atmospheric and fun at the same time.

I would be hard pressed to find any flaws in the game.  If I did, I would say that parts of the ending felt a little out of place.  Some of the scenes and actions didn't make quite as much sense as they could have, and the symbolism is a bit heavyhanded; but that's still a fairly minor quibble.   The game is a bit shorter than most of its type; but too much longer and it would have started to drag.  The pacing never leave it feeling too long or too short.

One warning is that the background story that emerges from the game is disturbing, becoming increasingly so the closer it gets to the end.  This is ultimately a story of addiction and child abuse; and is accordingly dark and sad.  Fortunately, the writers do not beat the player over the head with moralizing; and manage to balance the darkness with a keen sense of human resilience.  

I cannot recommend this game enough.  I picked it up at a huge discount during one of Steam's big sales; but would can easily recommend getting it even at full price.

12817648.review:
Papo & Yo is a 3D puzzle platformer that has great art, great concept and a moving story but suffers from clunky controls, lack of invention in the puzzles and some minor glitches.
7/10

The game tells a story of a troubled boy through a fantasy setting in a Brazilian favela. While the idea is great, the potential is not fulfilled since the way the story is presented fails to make you really identify and care for the boy. It has some fantastic moments but it feels like the creator lost some immersion in an effort to avoid making it depressing.
The puzzles are not hard and the resulting animations are great but all of them feel like a variation on the same puzzle. The platforming part is not hard either but the controls are definitely lacking. It is not accurate in movement and in depth causing you to miss simple jumps and redoing the part again.
The art style is really great. The scenes are beautiful and deliver wonderfully the favela feeling, especially the wall drawings. The characters are inventive and well animated and the subtle graphical effects really enhance the magical felling of the game.

I really liked the different direction this game is taking and I would very much like to see another title from this developer - hopefully with more attitude to the story and improvement to the technical side. Took me about 5 hours to complete the game.

12811256.review: this game counts as my token black friend so it was worth the purchase

12735521.review:
An interesting Indie platformer/adventure game with only a few minor things that set it back. I have to say it does remind me a lot of what Brothers: A Tale of Two Sons does in terms of story, conveying most of it through the gameplay and what you see rather than dialog, but this game does have dialog occasionally so its a little more clear sometimes what is going on. Even then though this game isn't what it seems like at first, without ruining it you will find out what the real theme is about and the metaphor for the monster as you go through.

You play as a kid, Quinco who comes across at one point a big monster, who has an unhealthy appitite for poison arrow frogs and a very bad temper; he eventually becomes your companion on the story as well as your little robot protector Lula. You are following a strange girl who claims you are "cursed" and are on a journey to find out what is going on, and where you really are. Through out you need to platform and solve puzzles to progress through the areas of the game, many revolving around the monster himself. There are no real boss fights to speak of in the game.

The game has some pretty good looking visuals, nothing that is going to push your machine to its limits but its very nice and the world itself very interesting and somewhat surreal at times. The game also has some fantastic music in it to go along with the visuals and perfectly fits the tone of the game and what is going on.

The game controls fantastically with a controller and KB+M, however despite the game implying you to use a controller, I personally at least found it to play better and be more enjoyable with keyboard and mouse, so the port gets that right. In terms of perfromace there really isn't much to complain about, there are certain times where the frame rate will drop but quickly goes back.

The issues with the game unfortunatly come from the design itself: while it is part puzzle game, the puzzles themselves aren't very challenging and are very itterative and repetitve, on top of that the game is short, very very short. Four hours is the most you can expect out of it, that's on first playthrough, but given how linear it is on subsequent playthroughs and knowing what to do, you could get through it in under three potentially. There is little incentive to replay the game too, outside of 25 hats hidden around the game to find, of which unlocks upon beating the game the first time. Besides that there are no other kind of collectibles or distractions, the puzzles, gameplay and story are the only attraction here.

The story attempts to be emotional and moving, which it does pull off many times, but at the same time once you learn certain things it kind of falls apart and become predictable and that hold it has wears off, doesn't ruin the game though by any means.

Overall, its a short, very easy, but enjoyable adventure through an interesting world and is charming at the same time. Its definatly worth playing through at least once, maybe twice if you are interested in collecting all the hats and achivements, but I cannot say I would recommend it at full price, but consider that part at your own discretion. All that said I did enjoy this game and I do recommend checking it out. None of the minor issues I mentioned are enough I think to deter from this nice puzzle/platformer.

12383988.review:
Papo & Yo is a 3D puzzle platformer adventure, in which you are a boy running after a girl, avoiding a monster while using it to solve puzzles, and playing with your robot toy. You use platforming to reach various stuff in the environment to change the the world around you to progress. Well, on one plane. On another plane, and this is made clear right before the game proper starts, this is a game about overcoming a drunk abusive father. Papo & Yo's story isn't the best, but it has a reasonably well put together theme and a very strong subject matter. There were a few story elements that felt somewhat jarring, taking you out of the immersion. For example, the tone of the girl changes dramatically and unexpectedly at times.

It's puzzles are on the easy side, all difficulty in this game comes from either finding the things you are to interact with or with your 3D platforming skills, sometimes together with a timed element in the  puzzle. Some times, it's hard to judge the distance to items and when using the robot overshoot. The platforming control does feel well implemented and I did not encounter any situations where I had managed to block progress by going somewhere I was not supposed to and with no recovery options.

Graphically, it's a nice looking game with a very consistent style to it. Textures and effects aren't the very best, but on the other hand, that's not really to be expected from a game like this. It does some world building through the environment, but over all, it is a very linear world that does not present mane chances for exploration outside of your immediate puzzle surroundings.

Game world isn't the largest, and the game doesn't take more than maybe 4-6 hours to complete if played with no prior knowledge, but for what it provides for the price, it is a solid and well designed game.

12366145.review:

Still, it's not a long game, it's charming enough that it doesn't deserve to be completely panned and ignored. Pick it up for cheap if you can.

12306484.review:
Buy? Maybe.

Long story short, Papo & Yo is another one of those obtuse and vague story telling indie games that will appear pretentious and confusing to many gamers or groundbreaking and wonderful for others. While I largely enjoyed the games easy, but not handholding puzzles and "Mystical chalk" in a Central/South American favela art style, I ended up mostly confused and not very satisfied with the ending. The ending was abrupt, and like the entirty of the storystelling, all based on metaphors. Papo & Yo is a game built more for the types that enjoyed Dear Esther (ugh) and Thomas Was Alone (A pretty nice game actually) and a bit less for those that enjoyed Portal 2 or Majin and the Forsaken Kingdom - the puzzles are nice, but hardly brain-teasing or super innovative. I will say that seeing how the world forms and deforms through puzzles solving is really interesting and neat, but like any pretentious indie game, it is never explained how or why parts of buildings can suddenly sprout legs to walk or wings to fly, or why entire towns can be split and connected like a jigsaw puzzle: You're just supposed to "understand" some nebulous meaning and interpret what is going on, like guessing "This is the kid's imagination or how he understand the world works because he is just a kid" or something like that. While it is also clear that this is supposed to be a story about a child and an unclear relationship to his father manifested in a frog eating monster representing an alcohol abusing father, the exposition is all metaphorical and based on the developer's artistic vision, It's less understandable like a good Pixar short or the "Kiwi!" film where you understand the actions and emotions.

If you need further proof of what I'm talking about, see the discussion thread about "What does it all mean?!" between players and developers, where the dev doesn't answer the question and instead thanks the players for debating what is going on: http://steamcommunity.com/app/227080/discussions/0/828936718797549690/

Papo & Yo gets on my good side for being a short, easy to finish game with a good art style, world design and an overall solid game (fits my Ultra-wide monitor resolution and I had no glitches besides a few graphical glitches early in the game). It gets on my bad side for being another "Guess at what story I'm trying to tell you instead of me actually telling you" arty/farty indie game. The story may strike a cord with other gamers who have experiened child abuse from their parents. This is something playable for children as well, but I doubt they would understand all the real world paralells the game is trying to make, Papo & Yo is essentially an adults game.

12289165.review:
I've heard some rumors that the original Xbox version of this game was buggy as hell, but I can assure you that I didn't stumble across any bug during my playthrough. Or well... just the kinda bugs that get stuck beneath your shoes.

Papo & Yo is a monument to how you fuse gameplay with storytelling. It's a symbol of how you can have an underlining depth without having to "show & tell" everything. It's also probably one of the most heartbreaking and terrifying stories to be told; a real story about real humanbeings (and children) living a real and painful life.
But like a good masterpiece of a movie it doesn't keep beating the motto of the story in your face constantly, like a sledgehammer with the words "Understand it yet?" engraved, it doesn't wrap you into a blanket of depression, and it doesn't reveal its' dark purpose from the get go. It's cute, it's happy... everything is wonderful 'til the drapes suddenly are pulled.

What about the gameplay? Oh man... it's a third person puzzle game where you play as a young boy stuck in an imaginary world in the Brazilian slums. Imagination is used almost to the point of Baron Munchhausen-standard and the graphics have a waltz with the imaginative world. And the music... everything is just so perfectly put together.

Just beware of one thing; when you reach the end... you will want to find the director of this game and give him a hug, because this is his story, and no humanbeing should be forced to go through what he did once upon a time.

Personal note; when it comes to storydriven games there are two kings of the hill that must share that gold medallion for me... it's Papo & Yo and Brothers - A Tale of Two Sons.

12180860.review:
First off: This game is short. Took me between 3 and 4 hours to complete it. So keep that in mind.

Now then, Papo & Yo is a heartwarming, uplifting tale of a child with a violently abusive alcoholic father.
There was some sarcasm there, see if you can tell where.

It's a puzzle game, and you lead the Monster (the child's father) around to help you solve puzzles in an effort to eventually help him. Problem is, you can't do much to help an angry drunk who doesn't think he needs help.

The game mechanics are fairly simple to grasp, although rather neat in execution, as you physically manipulate the slums around you to advance to the next area. If you're looking for a challenging puzzler, this isn't it. It's fairly unique, but not difficult. Nothing stumped me for more than maybe 15 seconds, and there's hints in the game if you do get stuck.

And there's little dialogue. They don't hit you over the head with the abusive father thing. You know it's there, and you know it's pretty bad. It isn't preachy about its message, it's just showing you how this child deals with the crap he's going through.

All that being said, if you can get Papo & Yo for cheap, it's not a waste of your money. Don't buy it expecting a great puzzle game on par with Portal. That will lead to disappointement. Buy it expecting a bittersweet story told in a simple manner with a few entertaining puzzles along the way. That will lead to a pleasant way to spend an afternoon.

11889781.review:
Just wow. Concise and poignant, this game is filled with sublime vistas of childhood wonder brought to life. The gameplay itself is elegant, and the mechanics reinforce the narrative of the game. I cannot say enough to convey how amazingly well executed the theme and story of the game is, from the devolving normalcy of the scenarios you encounter, to the sparse but powerful cutscenes that hit you like trainwreck. 

By the time I was done, I had become a bundle of emotions, both profoundly sad yet simultaneously uplifted by the ordeal I had participated in. The game reads as a catharsis on the part of it lead designer, Vander Callabero, and I wonder if its narrative could be, in part, healing for those who have gone through similar crises. I'd challenge anyone who doesn't believe that video games can be art to play this game and still support that opinion.

Stop reading this and just go and experience this story.

11886942.review:
PAPO&YO: 

Senza fronzoli, la storia è molto semplice e impattante: un bambino, un mostro come amico immaginario, un giocattolo coi super poteri e un amica sciamana. Semplice? Si. Giocatelo e ne avrete l'idea.
Purtroppo non si può parlare della storia senza farne qualche spoiler, perciò posso solo dirvi che vi troverete catapultati in un mondo tipicamente carioca, variopinto, colorato, vivace e vario, visivamente un piacere per gli occhi.
Il gioco è in sè è un platform/puzzle, molto semplice, poichè il suo punto focale è la storia.

Diciamo che difficilmente capirete subito di cosa si parla e perchè il nostro personaggio sta compiendo quel viaggio, ma dopo qualche ora di gioco tutto vi sarà più chiaro.

Il finale: non è nulla di epico, forse lo capirete da voi. Però, è una freccia dritta al cuore. 

Sapete, si dice che un gioco sia fatto bene se te lo porti dentro anche dopo averlo finito, beh, allora Papo&Yo non è fatto bene, è fatto benissimo.
Il tema di cui parla la stoira è attualissimo più che mai, e il modo di raccontarlo è unico nel suo genere.

E' tutto un crescendo di emozioni, un climax che ha il suo culmine nel finale del gioco.

E' consigliato a tutti, ne vale la pena, fidatevi.

11876811.review:
I loved "Brothers: a tale of two sons" and Steam thought I'd also like "Papo y Yo" but I didn't.
***
They're similiar in that both games have beautiful (and I can't emphasise this enough) scenery, great music and an emotionally charged story that eventually ends in drama. They're also pretty liniar and the puzzles don't require a brain surgeon to solve them. So why didn't I like Papo y Yo as much? Probably because it kept giving me hints where I didn't really need them, prolonged gameplay by making me run all over the place way too many times, gave away the story with its achievement list and kept moving the camera angle right when it was vital for the character to go where I wanted it to. Also, I felt like it was trying too hard to be a tearjerker but it didn't really find a way to get me connected enough to the characters so that I'd empathise with them.

I feel like it'd be a shame to not recommend this game, but 11 € seems pretty steep to me; if childhood trauma based games with good music and pretty art are your thing, by all means get it, but wait for the sale.

EDIT: My second playthrough was better as I avoided all hint and training boxes and I spent considerably less time running away from Monster - knowing your surroundings does come with a tactical advantage.

11861856.review: Поучительное приключение на пару вечеров, пытающееся показать, как бывает тяжело детям из неблагополучных семей... 11844754.review:
Hallo zusammen,

ich möchte mal meine Meinung zu diesem Spiel niederschreiben. :)

Erst mal zum oberflächlichem: 

Das Spiel selbst hat meiner Meinung nach eine sehr eigene aber wunderschöne Grafik und die Musik ist ebenfalls sehr mit Bedacht gewählt. Man kann sich richtig in Situationen und ins Spiel reinfühlen, da alles so super zueinander passt. Auch die Engine finde ich sehr einfach gehalten und die Idee des ganzen Spiels ist einfach... Es begeistert mich. Dieses komplette Spiel hat mich begeistert. Es ist – wenn man in solchen Spielen Übung hat – locker sehr schnell durch zu spielen. Ich würde sagen... Wenn man es in einem durch spielt dann dauert es ca. 2 Stunden. Will man noch die Errungenschaften alle machen, dann dauert es eventuell etwas länger, da einige nicht ganz klar beschrieben sind und man vielleicht Google zur Hilfe holen muss.

Kommen wir aber nun mal zur Story, denn darum geht dieses Spiel meiner Meinung auch am meisten. Was ich sagen muss ist, dass es nicht so super viel Handlung in diesem Spiel gibt – was aber auch absolut in Ordnung ist. Wenn man es erst mal angefangen hat, dann möchte man es höchstwahrscheinlich auch zu Ende spielen und dafür haben die Spielemacher auch gesorgt.
Die Stellen in denen man selbst die Figur steuert sind immer sehr knifflig gestaltet, man hat was zum denken und auch zum lachen, da gewisse Dinge in diesem Spiel einfach sehr drollig und süß gestaltet sind und die Videosequenzen mögen Anfangs vielleicht etwas verwirren, führen aber am Ende alle zu einem Draht zusammen und plötzlich geht einem ein Licht auf was alles zu bedeuten hatte.
Ich möchte hier nichts von der Geschichte niederschreiben, denn ich finde jeder sollte es einfach mal selbst durch spielen, da der Hintergrund der gesamten Geschichte sehr Herz erwärmend ist und mich sogar zu Tränen gerührt hat.
Dieses Spiel mag für junge Leute wohl eher nicht so viel aussagen wie für erwachsene Menschen die den Hintergrund von allem viel besser nachvollziehen können, meiner Meinung nach.

Ich kann auf jedem Fall nur jedem wärmstens Empfehlen, der schon gerne Spiele mit Hintergrund und Liebe in der Entwicklung und Gestaltung gespielt hat sich auch an diesem zu versuchen. :)

This game took me for a loop to say the least and I enjoyed every minute of it.  I would highly recommend this, however be aware it can hit you like a ton of bricks--but in a good way.  Congratulations to the makers of this game--you have reached more levels than one on this one.  Simply beautiful.

11774825.review:
I was expecting this to be a small indie title that was rough around the edges, which is why it was such a surprise.  This has the production values of a AAA title - whatever any of that means, but it would never be released and marketed as such.  You'll see amazing, world-bending things, things that haven't really got an equivalent in other games.

But you'll also get the point, which is why this could never really be an AAA blockbuster.  It's beautifully sad, and definitely not for everyone.  Mindful of triggers due to the subject matter, but without spoiling anything, I'll just say that the ending is as redemptive as you want it to be.

11773542.review:
Papo & Yo es un señor indie de pies a cabeza. 
Si bien tiene ciertas carencias, como su corta duración (aunque tiene un new game+ con ciertos extras que amplían su vida util), diversos bugs no muy importantes y que es un juego bastante fácil. Pero salvando esas pequeñas cosas, estamos ante una joya. Un juego con un trasfondo muy profundo sobre una historia que se da muy a menudo y la verdad es que cuanto más avanzas en el juego, mejor vas entendiendo el porque de cada cosa que hay en el mismo. No quiero spoilear, pero definitivamente tiene una buena historia y muy bien implementada en el desarrollo del título. La jugabilidad se basa en resolución de puzzles interactuando con el escenario, todo muy sorprende y logrado.

 Claramente no es un juego de 10 o el típico título AAA quiere acaparar lo máximo en el mercado,  pero merece ser jugado al menos una vez por cualquier amante de los videojuegos. Es realmente gratificante y sobretodo la épica ost le da un carisma único. Os lo recomiendo encarecidamente.

11758814.review:
Hym... Gra wygląda jak by była dla dzieci... Nie jestem dzieckiem, a podobała mi się! Mechanika gry, grafika i wszystko za wyjątkiem fabuły, sugeruje, że jest to świetna gierka dla młodych. Jednak fabuła, która wyłania się z postępem w grze, nie jest kolorowa i przedstawia dziecko, które uciekło do świata fantazji przed problemami rodzinnymi. Nie chcę zdradzać dlaczego, ale gra jest pogodna, odprężająca, z ciekawymi zadaniami i unikalnymi ich rozwiązaniami, a pod koniec poruszająca i dająca troszkę do myślenia jeśli trafiła na odpowiednią nutę, i zagrała w duszy...

Któtko o cenie... nie jest warta 40 zł. Polecam w promocji.

11709041.review:
Simplesmente surpreendente!!!
Nem lembro como ou quando adquiri este jogo, que estava lá "encostado" na biblioteca. E um dia, despretenciosamente decidi joga-lo e até agora ainda estou surpreso com sua qualidade, tanto técnica (gráficos e jogabilidade), quanto lúdica, o jogo tem roteiro, uma história que você persegue a todo momento (não é open world, mas e dai? Pelo menos você não fica perdido e tem um propósito a ser cumprido) e a simplicidade das ações e a "viagem" das soluções realmente tornam este jogo diferenciado.

Certamente haverá quem ache ele meio parado, e até infantil (Será?!), porém esta caracteristica light, te permite joga-lo com a familia, não te cansa e nem estressa, é divertido e não é tão "bobo" quanto Rayman pois o visual realista de bairros, humildes de qualquer parte do mundo geram uma sensação de realidade e apesar das soluções mirabolantes, não permite que o jogo torne-se um mundo de faz de contas.

Gostei muito,

11684580.review: Played through Papa & Yo today.Not a bad game. I remember the press on this being highly favorable. The gameplay wasnt really very challenging, but it was engaging enough to convey the story, which was obvious very quickly, so no worries about spoilers really...you (but really the guy who wrote the story) had an abusive alcoholic dad, and the torment of that upbringing haunted him throughout his life until he was finally able to let go of the fear and torment and move on with his life....that is pretty much the story in a nutshell. It is put forward in a very sensitive manner, and serves to explain the writers feelings without necessarily forcing them on you the gamer. So, I can see why people liked the game based on that. I think the gameplay was probably a 6 out of 10, but the story was more like a 7 out of 10, and the presentation was a 9 out of 10.

El diseño de puzzles y niveles es maravilloso, es realmente una experiencia que, al menos yo, recomendaría al 100%. Y eso si es que no nombramos la banda sonora, que esta bien producida y además combina demasiado bien con cada situación que se presenta.

No es todo, realmente deja un mensaje que todos deberiamos considerar. Vander da una conclusión basada en la cruda realidad de muchos.
Es un juego muy bonito, dejando a un lado el clipping que hace que objetos atraviesen el cuerpo de Quico, pobre Quico...

Lleva un concepto único que llega al objetivo inicial que tenia el equipo de desarrollo, captar las emociones.
Recomendado.

11618157.review:
This game is criminally underrated.
It stands side by side with another one of my favorite games Brothers: Tale of Two Sons as a shining example that a game can be fun as well as tell a beautiful story and have as much emotional resonance as any other type of art.
The theme of this game is so dark but is approached in such a beautiful way that the ending left me in tears.
And the game, though short (although I think the length is just right), has the right amount of difficulty.
The art direction was also wonderful.  I loved how the favela was not something you just navigated through but was integral part of the game.
I wish more people would play this.
More games should be like this.

11615711.review: First of all, I have to mention that this is quite a powerful game and can have quite an impact on people if they have ever suffered with or been aroud substance misuse although it isn't primarily focused on this. The gameplay is incredible. There is lots to explore and lots of creative elements involved such as making things in order to help you through your journey. Without giving too much away, you feel very much like you are the character playing and you quite often feel what he is feeling. This did make me cry, I will be honest but I personally, love games that has such a powerful impact on me. It makes me want to play it again and again and I have already completed the game twice and itching to go back. It's easy to forget yourself and get totally immersed. If you like adventure and a taste for real life elements, give this game a try. It was suggested to me by a friend and I can't thank him enough for putting me in touch with this game. I highly recommend it and I'm very thankful to the developers for going to so much trouble and effort to make it an amazing experience for me.

11468492.review:
I have mixed feelings about Papo & Yo.
On the other hand I want to love the game for it's unique feel, but on the other I feel it is lacking on many fronts.
At it's best Papo & Yo offers beautiful artwork and sceneries, entertainment and a fun challenge. At it's worst, it is very repetitive, frustrating and even boring. It also hosts a selection of glitches, that aren't that big of a deal, but do leave an unpolished impression.

The story had me intrigued at first, but lost me after a while because of it's slow progress. Also, it's really not well carried out tbh. I did however finish the game for I wanted to get to the predictable end. Seeing the credits scroll down on the screen didn't offer the satisfaction I thought it would, other than finally getting the game off my to-do list. It was a bit like finishing a mediocre book.

Still, I won't advice to steer clear of the game. If you have the patience and are willing to forgive some annoyances (many that are due to budget) Papo & Yo delivers a different kind of gameplay experience that other game makers should learn from and improve on. It is good to see that more and more people like Vander Caballero (the creative director, who the story is based on) take the effort to get off their high horses at big game studios to go and discover their own path.

11458805.review:
I'll say 8/10. If you are interested in this sort of game, you should play it. It is good, but it is not a great 9 or 10 game. 

It is a puzzle game, figuring out how to get from here to there, moving platforms, jumping, etc. The puzzles were varied and unique, and I was sometimes challenged, but never frustrated.

The plot is that you are a boy, running through a magical version of Brazil (maybe, I wasn't sure). You spend most of the game in a poorer section of the city, but you can pull levers to make buildings move. You have a beloved robot companion, a monster that follows you around, and a mysterious girl. 

But all of this is a dream, because in the real world your father is an abusive alcoholic. Monster, is of course, your father. Normally, Monster is Ok. You can use him to jump to higher ledges, or activate switches. He walks arounds, and sleeps a lot. But when Monster eats a frog he becomes a flaming demon of pain.

This game did a great job of controlling my emotions. In the beginning, Monster isn't so bad. Maybe even helpful. But as the game progressed, I found myself hating Monster. Really hating him. And hating frogs. I would smash every frog I saw, and I have never wanted to murder (no defeat, not slay -- murder) a monster more.

11449777.review:
To my mother, brothers and sisters with whom i survived the monster in my father..         - Vander Coballero


Шикарный платформер заставляющий задуматься!! Мы играем негритенком, у которого очень напряженные отношения с отцом. Однажды прячась от отца мальчик видит свечение на стене, которое переносит его в другой мир. В этом мире ему необходимо дойти до шамана решая головоломки. Помогать с ними нам будет Лула - любимая игрушка мальчика. Ключом к некоторым головоломкам будет монстр, который на нас никак не реагирует, но если он сожрет лягушку то тут же захочет сожрать мальчика. Умереть в игре нельзя, падать либо не высоко, либо в воду, ну а злой монстр всего лишь выбросит мальчика в сторону. Подсказки сделаны очень оригинально - надень на голову коробку, внутри нарисованы подсказки.))

Очень хороший сюжет, заставляет переживать за героев. Красивая, приятная глазу графика. Очень очень очень красивый саундтрек, который прекрасно сочитается с картинкой на экране, переносит нас в чудесный мир, и мы как будто находимся рядом с героем...

11439178.review: If you want to experience the thrill of Brazilian favelas in the timespan between the 2014 world cup and the 2016 summer olympics, Papo and Yo is your game.

11439099.review: More disclosure from me. I may be the world's worst platform puzzle gamer. I am absolutely terrible at these things. So going into "Papo y Yo" I was a little hesitant but the great reviews and the relatively short gameplay time had me thinking "why not". "Papo y Yo" is the story of a boy named Quico dealing with an abusive alcoholic father. While hiding in the closet he sees a chalk mark on the wall and ends up falling into a dream like world and for the next 3-4 hours you'll be traversing this world in order to find someone or something to help you cure the Monster (AKA your father's demons). I really enjoyed this game. The game world was incredibly cool and the soundtrack was excellent. The gameplay is standard puzzle platforming but other than a couple frustrating moments this wasn't difficult at all, even for a rank amateur like me.  Some might take issue with the game length but I found it perfect. The pacing was excellent and there wasn't a lot of time wasted. The game wasn't perfect. I did come across a bug or two that would screw up a couple of jumps here and there and the gameplay variety was a little lacking (pulls this, push that etc.). Some may also find the game a bit pretentious (the monster = Quico's dad, frogs = alcohol) but it didn't bug me at all and I found "Papo y Yo" to definitely be a journey worth taking. 8=10 from me.

11434836.review: This was one of the extremely few games I have ever played where I felt the story matched the gameplay. The puzzles, while rather easy, were still fun to execute, but that was forgotten as the graphics, music, and actual gameplay were absolutely beautiful. I adored this game.

11434572.review:
The gaming industry is at its best when a developer manages to turn a personal story into an enjoyable game. 

Papo&Yo is a wonderful experience: the gameplay is fun and gimmicky, turning the landscape and urban architecture into puzzles, thanks to all sorts of imaginary devices, the kind a child (or a talented graffiti artist :) ) might draw on walls. Many times I just surprised and delighted by what my next click did, never bored and always looking forward to the next area to solve.

The game looks and sounds just right enough to draw you into the world and the story it wants to tell. Just stand still in the sun, look around at the colorful houses of the South American slums and listen to the silence. And the crickets :) Just beautiful.

Everything feels organic, in its right place and I don't want to tell you anything more specific, for fear it will spoil your own experience. I'm just sorry I didn't pick this up sooner, it's been sitting in my Library for months.

Do yourself a favour and put a smile on your face with this gem.

Dieses Spiel beinhaltet ein Thema,was wirklich schockierend ist,Misshandlung durch den Vater.Wenn man das schon liest,dann weiss man ,dieses Spiel ist nicht fuer jedermann.

Ich habe es trotzdem gespielt und bin unglaublich überrascht,wie das Spiel auf einen wirkt.

Zur Story hab ich schon mehr als genug erzählt,Misshandlung durch den Vater.

Die Charakter sind wirklich etwas anderes.Es gibt 4 Hauptcharaktere,Papo,Quico,Alejandra und Lula,ein Spielzeug,das euch oft hilft.

Die Grafik ist klasse und man sieht,wie viel Arbeit in dem,recht kurzen Spiel ist.Viele Rätsel weisen euch den Weg und sind meist verständlich.

Zur Musikuntermalung muss ich sagen,das der Soundtrack super zum Spiel passt.Und dem Spiel eine tolle Atmosphäre gibt.

Die Steuerung ist,dank Gamepad,sehr handlich-ich hatte keine Probleme.Leute die mit Tastatur geübt sind,dürften aber auch mit dieser, keine Probleme haben.

Mein Fazit: Da dieses Speil recht kurz ist,sollte man,wenn man es spielen will,im Angebot kaufen,für knapp 4 Stunden ist der Normalpreis doch etwas teuer.Vom Wow-Faktor würde ich dieses Spiel mit Brothers A Tale of Two Sons vergleichen.Bei beiden bin ich von Story und Gameplay sehr beeindruckt.Wer ein storyhaltiges Spiel mit Charme und Atmosphäre sucht,sollte Papo & Yo auf jeden Fall mal ausprobieren!

11301557.review:
3D 퍼즐 어드벤처 게임. 남미의 마을 같은 묘하고 몽환적인 세계 속에서 주인공 Quico는 퍼즐을 풀이하며 게임을 진행한다. 이 세계를 아주 멋지게 표현했는데 그래픽도 그렇고 전체적으로 정말 말끔한 느낌이 든다. 곳곳에 있는 거대한 일러스트도 개성있고 독특하면서도 분위기와 묘하게 조화가 잘 된다.

 보기도 좋은데 음악도 분위기와 잘 조화되어 흘러나온다. 게임의 진행에 있어 필요한 '퍼즐'은 그다지 어렵지 않다. 그렇기 때문에 어느 정도 시간과 노력을 투자하면 게임 전체를 끝낼 수 있다. 어렵지 않은 퍼즐을 푸는데 그 퍼즐이 진행되는 구조 같은 것을 보여주는 것 역시도 아주 특이하고 '어떻게 이런 생각을 했을까?' 싶을 정도로 풍부한 상상에 기반한 표현을 보여준다.

 멋진 세계 속에서 좋은 음악을 들으며 크게 어렵지 않은 퍼즐을 풀어나간다. 처음에는 단순히 소녀를 쫓기 위한 것이었는데 괴물과 맞이하고 그와 함께 그의 도움을 받아 진행하게 된다. 내가 플레이할 때는 각종 요소들에 큰 의미를 두지 않고 퍼즐을 이리저리 풀어가며 게임을 진행해나갔고, 게임 중간 중간 Quico가 회상하는 장면을 통해서는 이게 무얼 뜻할까 하는 가벼운 생각만 있었을 뿐 무심코 넘어갔다.

 하지만 진행하면서 맞이하는 사건들의 연쇄 반응을 통해 극의 분위기는 고조되고 결국 극의 절정이 지났을 때 이 모든 요소들이 어떤 것을 비유하고 있었고, 요소 간의 관계를 통해 전달하려는 메세지가 있었음을 깨달았다. 그 메세지 속에서 난 공감대를 느낄 수 있었고 게임의 메세지 전달 수단으로서의 가능성 역시도 뚜렷이 확인할 수 있었기 때문에 큰 감명과 인상을 받을 수 있었다.

 게임을 통해 자신의 생각을 표현하려는 시도는 '아트 게임'이라 불리는 방향으로도 있고 많은 인디 게임에서 찾아볼 수 있는데, 이처럼 훌륭하게 게임의 목적과 전달의 목적을 둘 다 달성한 경우는 내 개인적으로는 본 적이 없다. 정신 없이 퍼즐을 풀다가 극의 진행이 절정에서 결말로 넘어갈 때 쯤 고요한 시간을 갖게 되는데, 조용히 그 의미를 곱씹으며 생각할 여유를 준다. 게임을 기획한 개발자의 경험에 바탕해 극이 짜여졌는데 겪은 바를 토대로 만들었기 때문에 더욱 감동을 줄 수 있었지 않았나 싶다. 누구든 한 번쯤은 플레이하면 좋을 것 같다. 특히 같은 아픔을 가진 이들이라면 더욱 이 메세지에 공감할 수 있을 것이다.

11149522.review:
I got this game a long time ago with an Humble Bundle, and finally got around to play it.
I'm really really glad that I did. I loved this game, its astounding ambientation, its nice puzzle nature.

Let's try to be objective and methodic:
-Story: 7/10
 The story isn't that great, but it's a break from classic puzzles, it's entertaining enough, and the end packs a punch.
-Longevity/Replay value: 4/10
 This is the worst part: it takes 3/4 hours to finish it, and once you finish it for the first time, there is really nothing compelling
you to play it again.
-Difficulty: 6/10
 Pretty much all the puzzles are very straightforward and easy to solve, with the hint box it's even easier. Both on the mental side and the skill required to put it in practice. Failing has no real consequences, as you never really "die" and the worst case scenario is losing a few seconds to respawn, but in the game everything stays as it was, so you don't even have to restart the level. This can be a pro (no frustration) or a con (shorter longevity).
-Aesthetic: 10/10
 This is the strongest point of the game. The ambientation, some kind of favelas, and the effect that solving the puzzle has on it is simply amazing. It has something mystical mixed with some kind of visual poetry. I greatly enjoyed it. Also kudos to the creators for the cure put into every little detail. Just lovely.
-Concept: 9/10
 Puzzles that change the conformation of the ambient surrounding you are not really so new, but not that common either.
Plus, the implementation is brilliant.
-Controls: 7/10
 Pretty straightforward. Usual wasd + mouse, third person. The cam is usually fine, in some rare occasion can move awkwardly. But those occasions are very rare, and failing has no big consequences (see "Difficulty")
-OST: 8/10
 The soundtrack is not, strictly speaking, memorable. But it always fit the game, is easy to the ears, nice, and really helps feeling part of the game.

AVG: 7.3
It's worth the 11€? I'm not sure. But I'm also pretty stingy.
What I can say for sure is that it's worth adding to the wishlist and get on a sale.

11143972.review:
Alcohol abuse can be a sensitive and personal topic and in this game it’s presented in a blatant, realistic and yet tasteful manner. This is due to the game being well designed, possibly due to the creative director’s own experience with an alcoholic father.

You never quite know whether Monster is your friend of your enemy. You have this constant sense of unease around him that he might find a poisonous frog and turn on you. But Monster is incredibly useful when he’s not charging you down. I also have to hand it to the composer, Brian D’Oliveira, for creating a light, flamenco soundtrack that ties in well with lightness of Quico’s steps and scenery. The story is well-presented and well-plotted, both visually, aurally and through the gameplay.

This praise all being said, the game isn’t without its flaws. Like many platformers, the game has an element of exploration which the designers failed to… explore. There’s plenty of nooks, crannies and hidey holes, but nothing in them. I even managed to find trapped teddy bears in many of them, but they seemed to be nothing more than coincidently-placed scenery. I felt that this beautiful and unique world was just a bit too empty, nothing to encourage me to play again and no reward for getting to these hard to reach places, not quite what I expect from a platformer

For full review, visit:
http://icarusreviews.net/2014/04/21/papo-yo/

11134315.review:
Kilka uronionych łez, przy zakończeniu gry, zastępuje chyba najdłuższą recenzję :)

Zanim tytuł uruchomiłam, obejrzałam kilka gameplayów, trafiłam też na wywiad z Caballero, twórcą gry i czułam, że to może być fabularnie, perełka. I nie zawiodłam się. 
Pierwsza połowa mija niezwykle przyjemnie. Głównym bohaterem jest chłopiec, którym poruszamy się po miasteczku, sprawiającym wrażenie ogromnego i niezwykle rozbudowanego (i chociaż ścieżki, którymi się poruszamy są dość ograniczone, wrażenie otwartego świata pozostaje). Prowadzi nas małomówna, tajemnicza dziewczynka, a naszym towarzyszem jest latający robot: Lula. 
Świat, chociaż wygląda normalnie, zawiera elementy tak abstrakcyjne, że każde pociągnięcie za dźwignię, wciśnięcie guzika w ścianie, może wiązać się z wywróceniem wszystkiego do górny nogami i sprawia, że każde zadanie staje się ekscytujące. 
Nie sądziłam, ze napiszę to o grze, która na pierwszy rzut oka wygląda na dziecinną bieganinę. 
Long story short: chwila w której świat zaczął zwijać się w rulonik, co automatycznie odwróciło sterowanie, była decydująca: ta gra stała się jedną z moich ulubionych i chociaż fabularnie trochę druzgocze, to wrócę do niej na pewno, aby zebrać dodatkowe osiągnięcia, które przewidują drugą rozgrywkę. A przyznam... że jeszcze nigdy nie uruchomiłam liniowej gry po raz drugi...

11131052.review:
Papo & Yo is a lot of things. It's a 3D puzzle game. It's interactive magical realism. It's a meditation on abuse and alcoholism. It's pieced together with a real familiarity with and affection for the assembled look of Brazilian favelas. And it has a autobiographical tone that's nearly impossible to find elsewhere in games.

The gameplay is decent. The setting and music are strong. But the real star of the show is Monster. The game couldn't exist without him. For a creature that says nothing and spends half the game sleeping, he's fascinatingly complex. You'll switch between trying to protect him and trying to escape from him at a moment's notice. You're trying to break his addiction, but sometimes you'll use that addiction to force him to do what you want. You'll find yourself clinging to the brief moments he shows some affection, even if it's nothing more than a half-assed toss of football. You want to like Monster, though you'll repeatedly ask yourself if you should even bother. It's a juggling act, but you'll find yourself practicing quite a bit of cognitive dissonance as you go from puzzle to puzzle.

The game isn't subtle in its metaphors, nor should it be. Think of it as a children's story about abuse. It's like Where the Wild Things Are, except instead of wild creatures as stand-ins for the anarchy of childhood, Monster stands for a child's perspective of the physical power, aloofness, and cruelty of adulthood.

Mais on sent l'intention des développeurs de transmettre un message, mais qui ne se fait pas forcément entendre, dommage. Le jeu est agrémenté d'énigmes, sympa, pas extraordinaire, mais pas non plus comptèment débile. Enfin, bref, Si vous avez 13 euros à dépenser et que vous voulez traverser une nouvelle expérience vidéo ludique, n'hésiter pas. En plus si vous pouvez l'avoir en promos, n'hésiter encore moins.

10945533.review:
Papa & Yo is a tale of a boy and his Big peach-coloured-monster that in a less than subtle way is a metaphor for an alcoholic parental figure. The monster likes bright orange coconuts and can be manipulated to go and stand at places that makes bright white magic happen. 

What's appealing about this experience is how this dream world is portrayed, and less so in how it functions.
The box city is vivid and playfully represented; cardboard boxes being picked up will make houses fly and move about to be placed in strategic places for our avatar to step on in order to progress.
Some houses will grow legs and move like cockroaches, others grow wings and fly.
I find these houses and what they mean to the main character more appealing than what the game tries to make me feel for the monster.

The monster is nothing but a tool for the main character to use in order to trigger bright white magic so that you can progress. I don't feel for the monster, and also with all this creative freedom that the kid has, why doesn't he make his way through without the monster? It means nothing to me as a player, there is no love.
The monster might just have been a ball and a chain locked to the kids foot.
And then when the frogs enter the picture, making the monster go inte a fiery rage when he consumes them, the monster's tediousness just increases making me like it less.
And liking it less would be fine if there just were some moment before that that established some kind of positive connection, but that never happens. 

It would serve whatever narrative the game is trying to convey better if the monster was simply always there, following and being present without forcing me as a player to make it go places all the time. 

But instead the game is tediously forcing the player to go through puzzles that after repetition loses what the game is trying to say about the relationship this kid has with the monster, the world, the girl, the robot and cardboard houses.

The movement felt when moving the character about is fluent and loose but comes to a chunky halt when the game demands you to yet again turn arbitrary levers in order to progress.
Or to make the monster do more stuff for you. Again.

I did enjoy what I played for the most part, with a little more thought put into what the puzzles could mean set to the context of what this boy is going through, it could've succeeded in saying something.

'Papa & Yo' has heart and genuinely cares, but needs more thought on how to make the theme of the game correlate with the player's choices.

10945250.review:
Papo & yo (papá y yo) cuenta el transcurso de la manera en que Quico, un niño de las favelas, asimila y se evade de los problemas que ocasiona tener un padre alcoholico agresivo creando metáforas como la del monstruo adicto a las ranas venenosas. Los gráficos los he encontrado geniales como para una desarrolladora de no muy alto presupuesto. La jugabilidad se basa en resolver puzzles (a veces se hace un poco cansino) con una estética bastante original que parte de un mundo imaginario en el que las cosas del entorno de Quico se transforman a su merced.

Vale mucho la pena jugarlo por la carga moral que le aporta el creador del juego.

10920035.review:
Ein ganz großer Diamant innerhalb des Genres der Adventure. Ein zweites Highlight was ich während der Sommeraktion 2014 erleben darf. Ich habe es gerade erst begonnen zu spielen, aber es langten schon ganz am Anfang ein paar Worte im Spiel, um meine Seele ganz tief zu berühren. Nein, es ist offensichtlich nicht das Geld, was ein Spiel kosten muss, auch nicht in jedem Falle die Komplexität der Inhalte, oder Rätsel, sondern das Thema und ebend diese seelenberührende Tiefe.

Wieder mal ein Spiel, was nicht bestimmt ist für Menschen, denen das Wort "Gefühlswelt" fremd ist. Das Spiel ist auch nicht gemacht für Menschen, die ewig lang tüfteln müssen, damit sie des Rätsels Lösng finden. Nein, hier bestimmt die Kreativität und die Aussage des Spiels.

Es ist mir eine Ehre, dieses Spiel erleben zu dürfen. Dafür sei den Entwicklern von ganzem Herzen gedankt !

Es müßte viel mehr solche Spiele geben, die nicht punkten mit der Höhe des Geldes, was sie kosten, sondern nur so sprühen vor kreativen Ideen, und von feinfühliger Umsetzung selbst erlebter, schwerer Dinge im Leben.

Danke dafür !

This game was the gone home before gone home. This games tells the the player a tragic story by having you play as a the son or victim of this tragedy. As you progess through the narrative... it becomes clear that this story is less about the art style and gameplay but more about telling the story of dealing with tragedy... that we don't often see in games nowadays. 

Don't exoect instant gratification or a great payoff. Invest your time in the story and you will come away feeling a lot better for having played this game. I remember pre-ordering this game and I normally do not pre-order a game of this type... but something compelled me to do so. I still can't find what truly compelled me because it is hard to put into words how satisfied I am for having played this game. 

There are very few games that I can hold the narrative and objective of the game in such high regard. This is one of them.

Not only is this a really fun puzzle platformer, it has a lot of heart and a great atmosphere. The story focuses on a boy and his toy robot that he wears like a jetpack for an extra boost to his jump. The game has pretty simple puzzles usually, but they often require some skill of the mechanics to pull off. The environments are all really beautiful in their own way and it was really interesting to see such a different setting like Brazil for a game like this.

The game also deals with a pretty simple, yet well implemented metaphor between the monster in the game and the boy's father. The best part about this narrative is that it explores these themes through gameplay and it's all connected and fits well within the game's design.

10854940.review:
At first I thought this game was just kind of a cheery little silly platform puzzler where you bounce around with chalk markings and floating magic sugar cubes, but as it progressed the story became revealed... the game actually got legitimately unsettling, even frightening at points. The story is very carefully revealed and if you don't get spoiled through reading guides or wikis, you'll be stabbed in the stomach with feelings. These aren't 'girly visual novel' feelings, these are 'I have never cried at a movie and I'm not scared of horror games; there's just something in my eye, please hold me' feelings. For some people, the topic may actually hit very close to home.

On a gameplay note, the gameplay itself is actually fairly simple though it can be periodically frustrating if you don't know what to do. It's a short-ish game, taking about 4 and a half hours to complete if you get stuck only on a couple of puzzles. Definitely worth it, especially if you get it on sale. I've had the game for over a year and I don't regret purchasing it.

Die spielerischen Elemente sind nett und geben ausreichend Tiefe, so dass man die doch recht kurze Spielzeit genießen kann. Aber wie bereits erwähnt, zielt das Spiel nicht darauf ab, möglichst innovativ in Sachen Spielmechaniken zu sein, sondern eine Geschichte attraktiv zu erzählen. Und das gelingt meiner Meinung nach. Ich war bisher noch nie so bewegt und nachdenklich, nachdem ich ein Spiel durchgespielt habe, wie bei diesem Spiel.

10776788.review:
I had read IGN's review of the fantastic Papo & Yo prior to playing, and I have to say; how wrong is Mitch Dyer? It's seems like he didn't have the patience for the simple puzzles and complained too much about the too few bugs, which were minscule.

And then I read Kotaku's review, and it was spot on: This game is a must play. It's imaginative, graphically impressive, the narrative is strong, the gameplay is simple enough. There's not too much wrong with the game. In fact, the only thing wrong with it might be some PC optimization, but lowering the settings a bit fixes that.

It was clear what the story was going to be about from the opening message and intro scene from the creative director and writer, a story about a boy with an abusive, alcoholic father. It's heartfelt and means well, but wasn't as inspired or hidden like how the masterpiece, Braid, shocks you at the end.

The game acts as a puzzler/adventure with platforming mechanics, jumping and stuff. It's done well, but a bit on the easier side. The puzzles were....simple, I guess is the best way of putting it. But it came with enjoyment, which Mitch Dyer didn't find it to be. The soundtrack and audio design is well done, I mean really well done. I was in awe of the composition and layering of instruments. Animation was fantastic, as expected; animators in Montreal do tend to put extra effort in their work. The graphics are visually impressive, great texturing, modeling, lighting, the favelas of Brazil are a great sight and I wish I could have seen more. But when the game starts to get more fantastical, the favelas become less important. The magical houses were sweet though. Also, fantastic lighting and shadowing.

I don't know what else to say, the game is great. Check it out.

9.0/10

10721761.review:
While this game took me only 4.8 hours to complete, I was incredibly pleased with the experience. It had just the right amount of semi-challenging puzzle solving and engaging story. The story is really what shines here, and the atmosphere and soundtrack really drag you into it. It's difficult to comment on without giving spoilers, but I will say that even if you had an amazing childhood with great parents, you'll still find the story heartwarming.

As far as the gameplay itself, don't expect anything too difficult. Most puzzle solutions revealed themselves in one to two attempts, and the platforming aspects were fairly easy, especially with a controller. This is not a game you'll be playing more than once, because once you see the story through to the end, there's nothing left. No replay value, but great first-play value.

10703162.review:
Papo y Yo is one of the most beautiful games I've ever played. I'm not even talking about visuals (though those were nice too!) It addresses some really mature subject matter that many people can probably relate to, in a hauntingly beautiful allegoric way.

Gameplay-wise, it's a puzzle-platformer with really clever puzzles. It does feel a bit slow at times (then again, don't all puzzle games? This isn't an FPS!) This is one of those "artful" games that you probably won't appreciate if you just want fast action and combat. The ending hit me particularly hard, as it was all too relevant to me, and this made every bit of the journey worth it.

I recommend Papo y Yo to anyone mature enough to handle what the game is trying to say.

10644068.review:
INCROYABLE ... ce jeu est magique !

Je n'en avais jamais vraiment entendu parlé et il ne faut surtout pas passer à coter. La force de Papo & Yo réside dans son histoire, qui reprends une histoire finalement assez répandu, en utilisant l'imaginaire de l'enfant qui aurait vécu cette histoire et qui la reviverait en rève (ou cauchemard). Ce qui rend la fin est assez dure moralement, si de plus vous avez vécu une histoire similaire ça le sera encore plus. Mais l'ambiance et les émotions sont parfaitement bien rendues, ce qui vous laissera pensif une fois l'avoir fini :) (par contre, le jeu est assez court, environ 3 à 5 heures pour l'histoire et autour de 8 heures si vous voulez faire tous les succès).

Pour ajouter une grosse profondeur à l'histoire, l'ambiance sonore est elle aussi de haut niveau, les musiques retransmettent parfaitement la philosophie du titre et le fond est vraiment enchanteur, de plus les personnages parlent dans leurs langues natale (qui n'est pour une fois pas l'anglais, ce qui aurait tué le jeu :p) et donc pour la traduction nous avons droit à des bulles comme pour une bd, ce que je trouve très bien intégré.

Coté gameplay, c'est un mélange de différents jeux prenons n'importe quel TPS, disons mass effect et acouplons le avec un jeu de puzzle genre portal puis avec un jeu de parkour genre mirror edge et pour finir avec une histoire forte genre braid et voila Papo & Yo ... tellement de genre dans ce jeu :) le tout parfaitement bien rendu. Le moteur graphique est l'unreal engine 3 donc des graphismes sympatiques et ne demandant pas une grosse config. De plus le jeu est vraiment pas chère et les promos sont assez fréquentes (et sur humblebundle, le jeu est déjà dispo sur linux, par contre sous linux il faut se battre pour avoir la traduction fr et le jeu demande beaucoup plus de resources que sous windows, le portage est plutot moyen donc).

10517076.review:
Papo & Yo is a truly excellent 3d puzzle platformer has great gameplay, great visuals, and a great story.

The main gameplay sees you solving a series of puzzles using what's given to you by the environment. Each puzzle introduces some kind of mechanic and the 3D platforming gameplay gives you an interface to interact with that mechanic. Discovering what that mechanic does then figuring out how to manipulate it to progress is key and the game does an excellent job of letting you explore the mechanics without punishing you for trying something that doesn't work.  If you mess up, the game gives you a way to come back from what you've done and in the few cases where you can fail (such as falling off a cliff), you get put back in quickly so you can try again. This is a great way to encourage players to explore their options and try anything they can think of and is an example of how to do puzzles well. None of the puzzles are repeats, so each puzzle gives you something new to chew on without any filler. All of the challenges are really well designed and fun, while there were one or two puzzles that got a bit tedious, I wouldn't say any of them were unenjoyable. I did encounter one glitch where my character got stuck and couldn't move, but other than that everything was pretty solid.

The graphics of this game are excellent both artistically and technically. Unreal Engine 3 is being used in full force to create a game that looks nothing short of gorgeous. The game uses lighting and bump mapping to great effect, but this would be mean nothing without the creative visuals that the developers put on display. The game more or less take place inside the protagonist's imagination (that's not a spoiler by the way), so they get really creative with the environments. The color pallete is vibrant and absolutely beautiful to look at. The animation of the monster is also fantastic, although the player character's run cycle felt a little bit stiff. 

Unlike most indie games that run on Unreal Engine 3, this game is actually extremely well optimized, and my GT 440 (which is somewhat old and outdated by now) usually got around 40 FPS on max settings.

Even though the gameplay and graphics are fantastic, the story just might be the best thing about Papo & Yo. I won't go into too much detail because that would spoil it, but the storytelling does a great job of telling a deep, emotional story in a mostly nonverbal way. What you see in the imaginary world of the character's imagination is allegorical to his life (and the life of the creator of the game), which makes the game feel the developer is opening up a very personal part of his life to you. It's emotional and beautiful there are some soulcrushing twists along the way.

Overall, Papo & Yo is a must-play for anyone interested in puzzle games or great stories.

10512290.review: A very heartfelt, metaphorical story with wonderfully creative level design and a childlike imagination to its puzzle mechanics. Highly recommended.

看到好友玩这个游戏，查了下评测 才发现没写评测，哎呦，我记得这游戏的评测我写过…又记错了？ …最近是不是健忘症……怪了。

这是一款动作解谜游戏，ign给了4分的低分。但其实很多人都觉得这游戏与这个评分不符。听说是小编 被ps3上的各种bug坑残了，于是对pc版也给这么低的分。谁知道呢，反正我不太在意游戏评分。游戏对大部分玩家来说只是一个合不合口味的问题，评分高也许合大多数人口味，但对自己来说喜不喜欢终究还是要自己尝过。

游戏里面各种独特的拼凑，其实充满着象征，很多时候很值得细细斟酌。周围的涂鸦、建筑风格还有人物的故事据说融合了游戏创意总监童年的回忆，看起来貌似很眼熟的贫民窟……难道是巴西，那种依山而建密密麻麻的……？

谜题很简单，用青蛙来吸引怪物帮助你不断前进。其实游戏的谜题不是重点，展现出的各种童趣和对家暴问题的映射才是核心。

入包的游戏，很有争议的作品，大家不妨玩一下，品味一番。

10333571.review:
Игра-метафора.
Нетривиальным способом решил поделиться о своём прошлом Vander Caballero (один из разработчиков). Интегрируя себя с мальчиком Кико, он рассказал игровому сообществу о проблеме, царящейся в его семье. Жаль, что в нашем мире такое детство у ребят не редкость.

Когда ты маленький и не можешь защитить сам себя, то ничего не остаётся, кроме как зарыться в уголок и воображать дивные мира,  где ты пытаешься спастись и одновременно вылечить собственного отца. Так и случилось с Кико, героем этой картины, спрятавшимся в шкафу, где он решил выйти из реальности.

Очутившись в параллельном мире, Кико начинает познавать его, знакомясь с взбалмошной девчонкой Алехандрой  и другом-роботом Лулой. Если первая шкодит до определённого момента, дразня Кико, то вторая сразу становится верным спутником и помощником в преодолении препятствий. Но есть в игре ещё и третий персонаж, который является немаловажным. Встретив в первый раз Монстра, он кажется таким добродушным и спокойным, разрешает прыгать у себя на животе, но всё меняется, когда на пути появляется лягушка.  Из безобидного Монстра он превращается  в настоящее чудовище, которое в буквальном смысле портит жизнь родным и окружающим людям. Вроде как есть проблески надежды, но всё тщетно…

Встречающиеся на пути головоломки лёгкие, быстро решаемые (в некоторых моментах может надоесть беготня от Монстра),  музыка приятная, меняющаяся в зависимости от обстоятельств и этапов решения загадок, продолжительность умеренная, локации красивые, с необычными  трансформациями (это же мир, созданный Кико, поэтому он может давать жизнь любым объектам),  эмоции присутствуют, некая загадочность тоже есть. Хочется отметить, что на стенах частенько встречаются граффити, но я их значение не понимаю. 

Papo & Yo даёт почву для размышлений, что является несомненным плюсом. Конечно, каждый найдёт что-то своё, а те люди, которые пережили нечто похожее в своём детстве, наверняка сразу раскусят задумку Кабаллеро.
Мне понравилось «наблюдать» за происходящим, одновременно сочувствуя и ненавидя Монстра.

10320209.review:
Papo & Yo è un avventura in terza persona basata sulla risoluzione di puzzle. E' un gioco indie con una spiccata direzione artistica e una grossa componente psicologica.

GAMEPLAY

L'anima "platform 3D" del gioco non è mai troppo marcata ma presente e spostamenti più o meno acrobatici saranno all'ordine del giorno. Lo scopo del gioco è quello di risolvere puzzle mai troppo complicati ma molto suggestivi. La natura delle problematiche da affrontare risiede nella ricerca e nel posizionamento di oggetti, nella loro combinazione con serrature o "locator" e nell'interazione con "Mostro", il nostro misterioso e lunatico "bot da addomesticare".
Tutti i vari puzzle (molto semplici) girano intorno a queste meccaniche e nulla più, ma garantiscono un livello di sfida comunque vario a livello situazionale.

ESPRESSIVITA' ARTISTICA

Il grande valore di questo videogioco è nella sua grande espressione poetica e psicologica. La storia in se è una grande catarsi, un viaggio inconscio in un iperuranio onirico costruito su una "favela delle meraviglie". 
L'ambientazione rispecchia i sentimenti e la fantasia di Quico, il suo mondo di gioco, i suoi tormenti interiori. Disegnare con un gessetto bianco può trasformare un decadente quartiere in un immenso parco giochi fatto di "simboli attivi", pulsanti di vita, mentre elaborati murales pieni di colori faranno da sfondo alla volontà di fuggire da una realtà grigia e stantia. 
Il temperamento sciamanico (che sempre alberga in ogni bambino e che spesso scompare nell'adulto), sarà lo strumento di purificazione da quell'inconfessabile verità che andremo a decifrare svelando la metafora che definisce il gioco. 
La caratterizzazione psicologica dei pochi personaggi presenti è curata in modo magistrale. Le stesse movenze e posture sono motivo di linguaggio psicologico. Il magico quartiere favela è definito con texture ed effetti di luce contrastanti, sempre molto luminosi, quasi a trasmettere un paradossale estetica paradisiaca al tutto.

COMPARTO TECNICO

Il classico Unreal Engine 3 viene sfruttato soprattutto per i suoi effetti di luce. Il gioco ha qualche problema di framerate nelle parti più "cinematiche" con PC non proprio pompati, ma ciò non compromette l'esperienza di gioco.

PRO

Grande immersione psicologica in un universo originale e profondamente artistico. Il mistero e il simbolismo sono trainanti. 
I puzzle sono ben congegnati e hanno una difficoltà a misura di quello che il gioco vuole trasmettere: una poesia costruita su un gameplay semplice.

CONTRO

Forse troppo semplice. L'avventura dura molto poco.


CONCLUSIONI

E' Arte, non nel gameplay, ma nell'espressività visiva, nel simbolismo, nell'esperienza psicologica che ci fa immergere in un dolce mondo di fantasia pieno di pathos. Se vi piacciono le avventure misteriose e avete uno spiccato senso artistico questo gioco fa per voi. Se invece non siete persone che si lasciano trasportare lo troverete un gioco troppo facile.

P.S.

Mi conta zero ore di gioco perché l'ho giocato in treno offline... non vi preoccupate no mi sono fatto di acido lisergico! XD

10307193.review:
This is right up there with Psychonauts for best game ever. It's a puzzle/platformer with emphasis on the platforming elements.

The puzzles are usually quite easy to figure out on your own, but sometimes quite difficult to enact. For instance, there's a level where you have to catch three frogs and destroy them before Monster catches you, and if you fail you start over from the beginning. It's the closest to dying you come in this game, but it's still quite frustrating.

I expected the story to be heart-rendingly moving, and I was still caught off-guard by it. It's that powerful.

One of my favorite things about this game is the setting. It looks like a favela if you look at it out of the corner of your eye, but if you explore and pay attention, you sink deep into the art and mood. It's one of the most fantastic and magical places that I've ever been in a game world. And just to emphasize this, you must revisit each level (except two of them) twice or sometimes three times, each time to do something different, and requiring a different perspective, which truly gives the city a sense of extent and volume. It's also so amazing the way nature and more magical eliminates insinuate themselves into the city, as if the city itself is invading something far older.

The mechanics of this game are also unique in a very well-thought-out way. For instance, most of the puzzles require you to rearrange the world itself, moving, stacking, and tipping the little shacks, and at one point, tipping the whole village on its side. This is the first game I've seen where you get the ability to make "long jumps" from another character (a rocket-propelled robot action figure named Lula) which can be detached from your character at will. Which means the game can take away your ability to jump far at any time, just to make the gameplay more interesting.

While I will say that this world drew me in so far, I didn't want to leave, and so felt a bit of withdrawal when the story ended after four hours, I can't help but note that the story arc is so smooth and coherent, it could not have been longer than it was. It ended exactly where and when it had to end. Given how little gaming time I have these days, it's probably best that it didn't take longer than it did.

Pros:
- Heart-rending story lovingly told
- Beautiful sets and models
- Clever game mechanics
- Just the right amount of frustration

Cons:
- The feeling of sadness slowly sinking into your soul the moment you beat the game and realize you must go back to real life now

Out of five, I'd give this game at least a seven.

10208271.review:
The colors and magic of the world of children, tainted by the darkness and harsh reality of the adults. I will not dwell on what happens in the game, as some might consider that to be spoiler territory.

On the gameplay side, this is a puzzle game where reality bends and changes at will, leading to a sense of magic and surreality that is extremely pleasing. 

For thoses who don't like to think too much about puzzles, there are always hints to guide you, if you ever need them. They are optional, so you're never forced to read a hint if you don't want to. On the whole the puzzles are a bit like Portal : you stop for a while trying to figure it out, and then you have an ha-ha moment and manage to move forward. So not complicated, but give you just enough pause to make it satisfying to solve it.

I really enjoyed the game, but got slightly frustrated toward the end. The game almost overstays its welcome. The goalpost keeps moving forward, you often think "this is it, i'm gonna see the ending", but there is actually one more puzzle to solve, and then another one, etc...Still on the whole the game is short enough for its own sake, and it's really worth to go through all of it to see the well crafted ending, and understand exactly what the game was all about.

10207853.review:
Papo & Yo ist eine schön erzählte emotionale Geschichte eines Jungen und eines Alkoholiker Vaters den er als Monster sieht.

Сложно сказать, чем же на самом деле является эта игра. Она слишком проста для паззла, слишком примитивна для бродилки, и слишком ненасыщенна для платформера. В ней есть оригинальные идеи головоломок, трогательный сюжет и отличная музыка. Но после пары минут восторга от каждой новой задачки, сразу приходит чувство повторения одних и тех же действий: головоломки сразу понятны и очень затянуты, хочется побыстрее их решить. 
Сюжета дается в час по чайной ложке, и до самого финала вообще не понятно что и зачем мы делаем, словно в игре история отдельно, геймплей отдельно.
То, что хотели сказать авторы, приходит в самом конце игры, но доставить свое "послание" глубоко они не смогли.

В любом случае, это качественный инди-проект, и с интересом пройдется за 3-4 часа.

10176650.review: Papo & Yo is a fairly short indie puzzle/platformer game that doubles as an elephantine metaphor for the game's creative director's troubled relationship with his father. The puzzles are fairly simple, but the way you interact with the world is interesting and the visuals are fantastic. Think of it as Portal, but with child abuse and alcoholism instead of cake and fat jokes. If nothing else, it is an interesting experience that doesn't overstay its welcome.

10155050.review:
Papo y Yo tiene una buena idea: narrar un trauma infantil de una manera afable. Bien. A partir de ahí, todo más o menos va cuesta abajo. La jugabilidad no está mal, una mezcla de puzzles con algo de plataformas, pero a los 15 minutos ya más o menos has visto todo y sólo te queda repetir los escasos patrones jugables en distintas (pero básicamente iguales) situaciones. Y la historia no anima a avanzar, narrada como está de modo muy superficial y bastante errático, de modo que no consigue generar vinculación alguna entre el jugador y los sucesos que observa.

Gráficamente, no está mal para ser un juego indie hecho por un grupo pequeño, y destacan de hecho algunas animaciones de objetos inanimados que son bastante divertidas, inesperadas y originales. Pero eso no quita que a nivel de diseño se repite infinitamente, dando vueltas una y otra vez a entornos que vienen siendo básicamente iguales. Y el sonido no lo arregla, pues ni la música ni las voces (escasas) tienen ni gran calidad ni aportan una atmósfera sorprendente. 

Todo lo cual lo deja en una buena idea, pero pobremente realizada. Un 3,5.

10086972.review: Well, my first ever steam review.  I HAD to review this.  A of hardcore gamer for over 30 years, this is the only one that warrents my time writing and promoting.  This game is beutiful.  It is really clever, artistic, imaginative, visually stunning, charming, wierd, warm, cold, gripping, mesmerising,  refreshing, and has a deep emotional story line like no other game before it  (or probably ever will ).  And on top of  this the gameplay is excellent,  the puzzles are clever, amusing and addictive.   A lot of care and thought has gone into this game.  Its a true escapist adventure.
