ค้นหาปมจิตใจในโลกเพ้อฝันแห่งจินตนาการของเด็ก

เกม Action Adventure ที่ออกมาได้ซักพักนึงแล้ว แต่ผู้เขียนก็ลืมๆ ไปเพราะช่วงที่ผ่านมาเกมออกเยอะเหลือเกิน แต่หลังจากที่ได้สัมผัสความสุดยอดของ Brothers - A Tale of Two Sons แล้ว ก็เลยโหยหาเกมแนว Adventure ที่ได้อารมณ์สุดยอดแบบนี้อีก ซึ่ง Papo & Yo เป็นอีกเกมที่ตอบโจทย์ความต้องการตรงนี้ได้ดี ตัวเกมว่าด้วยเรื่องราวของเด็กที่เกิดเหตุการณ์รุนแรงกับชีวิตทำให้มุมมองของเขาต่อพ่อเปลี่ยนเป็นเหมือนปีศาจร้าย ซึ่งนั่นนำพาตัวเขาเองไปสู่โลกเร้นลับที่เกิดขึ้นบนโลกเสมือนจริง เดินทางค้นหาทางออกให้กับชีวิตของตัวเองเพื่อปรับมุมมองของเขาต่อพ่อให้ได้ และเผชิญกับปริศนาในโลกแห่งมิติที่บิดเบี้ยว และมุมมองที่มีต่อโลกใบใหญ่ของเด็กคนหนึ่ง

	ตัวเกมนั้นเป็น Action Puzzle ที่จะต้องอาศัยการสังเกตฉากต่างๆ ให้ทั่วถึงและใช้ความสามารถในการแอ็คชั่นต่างๆ ของตัวละครเพื่อไปยังจุดต่างๆ ของฉาก และต้องสังเกตสิ่งรอบข้างให้ละเอียด ซึ่งตัวฉากออกแบบมาได้อย่างสร้างสรรค์ และทำให้เนื้อเรื่องซีเรียสและน่าติดตามขึ้นมาได้ถึงแม้ปมของเรื่องจะไม่มีอะไรเลยผ่านการเล่าเรื่องที่แปลกแหวกแนว และค่อยๆ เฉลยปมออกมาทำให้เข้าใจเนื้อเรื่องทีละน้อย ยิ่งถ้าหากใครได้ติดตามตัว Teaser Trailer ที่ทางทีมพัฒนาปล่อยออกมาเรื่อยๆ แล้วล่ะก็ จะยิ่งอินไปกับตัวเกมมากขึ้นไปอีก ในส่วนของเพลงประกอบนั้นทำออกมาได้ยอดเยี่ยมมาก ความยาวของตัวเกมก็อยู่ในระดับที่กำลังดี จะมีก็เพียงในส่วนของการเคลื่อนไหวตัวละครที่ยังแข็งๆ และมี Bug อยู่บ้างประปราย แต่นั่นก็ไม่ได้ทำให้เกมลดความสุดยอดลงเลย 

สรุป: ตัวเกมออกแบบโลกได้สร้างสรรค์ เหมือนสิ่งที่เกิดขึ้นในจินตการของเด็ก หรือสิ่งต่างๆ ที่เด็กอยากให้เกิดขึ้นในโลกส่วนตัว ซึ่งปริศนาต่างๆ และการเล่าเรื่องทำได้อย่างน่าติดตาม แต่บั๊กและการเคลื่อนไหวตัวละครยังมีน่าติบ้างหลายจุด 

ข้อดี:
- ปริศนาสร้างสรรค์
- เล่าเรื่องได้น่าติดตาม
- เนื้อเรื่องเหมือนไม่มีอะไร แต่แอบดราม่าและแฝงความโหดร้ายเอาไว้
- เพลงประกอบยอดเยี่ยม

ข้อเสีย:
- บั๊กเยอะมาก
- ตัวละครยังแข็งๆ อยู่
- ระบบฟิสิกส์ในบางจุดยังไม่สมจริง

Score: 91/100

8630703.review:
I am outraged that I have never seen this game before getting it in the Humble Bundle. The fact that Papo & Yo got almost no attention while Gone Home got game of the years, 10/10s, and several thousands articles written about it frustrates me to no end. Not only is Papo & Yo a good game, it does more for story telling and social commentary than any video game I can think of.

Here's the important part first. Purely as a game, it is a good game. The player is required to solve a series of platforming puzzles that gradually become more complex the further in they go. None of them were incredibly difficult. Most of the difficultly comes from figuring out how you're suppose to use a new mechanic or item and then adding it to larger problems. Using the classic system of introduce, teach, then impliment, it makes sure the player is never confused. I was only once stumped enough to restart the level, thinking I had broken the game. However, I had just not been looking hard enough at the answer staring me in the face. Other than solid platform puzzling there's nothing completely amazing. It does what it does well and is definitely worth the Humble Bundle price.


Now for extra bullox. 
Papo & Yo is not 2deep4you. In fact, it states the symbolism of the monster in the first few seconds of starting the game, but everything about the game manages to be abstract enough to make the player think and form their own interpetations. It is rather light on story, focusing instead on the gameplay itself. What this game aces is the use of gameplay to tell the story. From the beginning, the player should know that the monster is an abusive parent, but nothing else is ever stated. The interaction between the boy and the monster in the form of puzzle solving mechanics reveals their relationship. There is no walking around reading notes. Very little of the story is spoon-fed. This combination of gameplay and story is what makes Papo & Yo so fantastic. It is telling a story about social issues by the means of a video game, not by a collection of text files.
And the best part is that this social commentary goes beyond first-world, white people problems. It covers problems of child abuse, alcoholism, and class issues, which I feel are much bigger problems in the world than sexuality. Quite honestly, I didn't understand the story at first because I have never been in any similar situations. Still, I was able to feel for the central characters far more than any other attempts at video game social commentary because I was involved with the basics of the relationship through gameplay.
If video games want to be taken seriously [spoiler]they never will[/spoiler] , they need to bring to light world issues that don't involve the internet and Papo & Yo does that excellently.

I'm sure someone else could say this far more eloquently than I ever could. Papo & Yo is a good game and is a fantastic example of how to mix gameplay and a serious, non-action story into an enjoyable and emotional experience.

This game takes you in a world where physics as we know them dont exist. It just plays with the world and its setting... and with you. The puzzles are pretty easy but I didnt buy the game because of them - more likely because of the story.

This game is fun. It is also kinda sad. You feel alone. It is metaphorically dark. It starts with a dedication reading: "To my mother, brothers and sister, with whom I survived the monster in my father." Obviously his father is the monster in the game. It is pretty easy to decipher.

8602657.review:
I videogiochi sono l'ottava arte. Questo ormai è evidente a tutti gli appassionati. Papo & Yo è una storia, breve, ma raccontata con empatia e arricchita da un tocco delicato di espressionismo astratto. A differenza di molti altri "art games", la narrazione è ben mescolata alla parte di "gioco" che ci si aspetta di vedere. Certo, il giocatore medio resterà deluso dalla brevità e dalla relativa semplicità dei puzzle; tutti gli altri potranno godersi con calma la genialità del level design e lasciarsi coinvolgere da una trama, già vista forse, ma mai prima d'ora vissuta da questo punto di vista inedito e proiettata in modo tanto magico su schermo.

Voto: ★★★★

8599125.review:

Purtroppo i puzzle non sono molto intricati nè originali. È un gioco molto facile.
Vale la pena comprarlo per l'ambientazione e per la storia (vissuta dal creatore stesso).

Lo consiglio a chi vede nei videogiochi un modello multimediale artistico, oltre che ludico.

8587937.review:
Well that was emotional...

Essentially a series of spacial puzzles set in a 3D world, you play the part of Quico as he seeks to remove his friend Monster's anger by taking him to a shaman.  As we progress we see that Monster is something of a metaphor for Quico's sad past.

The story is delivered with confidence and impact.  The puzzles throughout, whilst not difficult, require some thought and a fair amount of spacial awareness.

All in all you're looking at 4 hours of fantastic playtime with a satisfying ending.  A second playthrough includes a now-unlocked side mission in which you must locate a collection of dolls, giving you a fine reason for a second playthrough.

I had one small problem with the game crashing.  A search about found it's not an uncommon issue, but no-one seemed to have an answer that worked for me - but sure enough verifying the cache in Steam fixed it for me and it didn't happen again.

8562632.review: A visually beatiful game that tells the story of a little boy and his strugle with his alcoholic father. The game is short, only about 2-3 hours, and has limited replayability (two times), but none the less is a must play for just about anybody who enjoys Indie games. Puzzles get harder as you go, but not too hard. However, the best part of the game is its graphics. They are astonishing... Especially, in the end... I has some humor in the game too (like some frog genocide), that makes it entertaining. Thank you to developers for a great game...

8548440.review:
Finally took time to run through anf complete this game. I must say, it is indeed very beautifully done! Artisitc world and character design, vivid colors, poetic soundtrack, this is a game everyone should play!

Though on the surface Papo & Yo appears to be one of the most abstract of games with no direct meaning, playing further into the game (and nearing the end) tells you the imaginary story of a boy, Quico, and his life of being bullied and abused (probably on a daily basis).

Monster, poisonous frogs, the robot Lula, all have their reason and place in Papo & Yo. The story will form really well when you play it through, when you will uncover the mystery of this awesome game.

8523991.review:
Magnífico.

Papo & yo transforma o drama da infância de  Vander Caballero em poesia.

Desde a dedicatória você sabe que jogará um drama, porém transformado em um lindo sonho de criança e com metáforas de alvos bem evidentes.
A favela e tudo a volta de Quico estão entre os cenários mais lindos e simples que já vi. Tudo isso na companhia de um robô e um monstro, ambos lhe ajudarão nos puzzles, mas o monstro lhe atrapalhará em seus incontroláveis ataques de raiva causados por seu vício.
Os cenários e personagens cativantes lhe acompanham até o fim, no qual você tem a certeza de que cada detalhe ali não era em vão.

Papo & Yo é mais um indie dessa nova geração de jogos/contos, mas faz isso de uma forma tão perfeita que todos deveriam jogar.

Eines der wenigen Spiele bei dem man nach dem Ende entweder fassungslos oder betroffen die Credits ablaufen lässt. 
Ein Spiel das eigentlich kein Spiel sein will, sondern vielmehr ein Versuch mit einer ganz persönlichen Erfahrung, einem prägendem Lebensabschnitt, umzugehen. Wenn man sich auf das Spielgeschehen einlässt, kann der anfängliche Spielspass sich recht schnell in Wut, Entsetzen, Trauer, Verstehen ändern. Es liegt soviel Persönliches in diesem ganz anderen Spiel, dass man vielleicht einen anderen Blick für gewisse Dinge im Leben entwickelt.
Mich hat das Spiel noch sehr lange nach Beenden beschäftigt und hin und wieder ertappe ich mich dabei wieder an den kleinen Jungen zu denken, der einerseits hilflos aber doch mit größter Zuversicht versuchte seinen ganz eigenen Dämon zu besiegen.
Danke das es solche Spiele gibt :)

What a surprise this game was!  First of all the colors and level design in this game is just gorgeous.  I don't want to spoil any of this game but the few characters, creatures, and items just work wonderfully with the game's mechanics as well as with its story. 

The puzzles (which range from Inception-like world manipulation to simply 'turn all the switches') feel so satisfying and are usually straightforward making this a constantly enjoyable experience. 

The game is short as it took me about 3 sittings to play through it.  But I don't think that any part of this game was lacking.  It was consistently great to play though and is absolutely the most underrated game of 2013 for me.

8430761.review: On ne joue pas vraiment à Papo & Yo pour ses qualités ludiques. Non pas que ce jeu de réflexion/plates-formes (une sorte de Limbo en 3D) soit désagréable à prendre en main, mais ses énigmes sont peut-être un peu trop légères pour accrocher le joueur, son gameplay manque de piquant et de précision, enfin quelques bugs peuvent entraver la progression (n'hésitez pas à relancer un chapitre le cas échéant). Et en plus il est court. Du talent mais pas de génie, un bon jeu mais pas un indispensable. On aurait même pu le ranger aux côtés du sympathique Deadlight s'il n'avait cette petite brise d'émotions en plus. Car c'est bien de son supplément d'âme que Papo & Yo tire toute sa force. Perdu entre le pays imaginaire et l'Amérique du Sud, porté par des musiques d'ambiance très réussies, Papo & Yo se sert du prétexte vidéoludique comme d'un tremplin narratif, utilisant les codes du jeu vidéo pour déployer peu à peu une métaphore aussi belle et naïve que grave. Papo & Yo n'est pas que l'histoire d'un petit garçon et de son gros monstre. A vous de le découvrir si vous avez déjà rayé de votre liste tous les meilleurs et les plus gros morceaux de la scène indépendante.

Un jeu d'aventure plutôt joli, une architecture particulière des décors. Aucune difficulté mais ça reste intéressant tout du long avec pas mal d'idées "originales". L'histoire est narrée via quelques moments clés dans le jeu, notamment des flashbacks mais j'aimerais éviter de trop spoiler. En tout cas elle a une place centrale dans le jeu.

Pour 3€, ça valait le coup. J'ai pris [url=http://steamcommunity.com/id/Harest/screenshots/?appid=227080&sort=newestfirst&browsefilter=myfiles&view=grid]3 petits screens[/url] mais ça spoile du décor donc si vous voulez le faire et découvrir vous même, évitez de regarder. Même si bon y'a rien d'exceptionnel non plus.

Pas de défaut particulier, à part le fait de devoir refaire le jeu pour récupérer des chapeaux... Il n'y a concrètement aucun intérêt à refaire le jeu puisque rien de change. Si ce n'est que les ours en peluche que vous rencontrez lors de votre première partie et qui ne font rien, auront lors de votre 2ème partie des chapeaux sur eux à collectionner pour... un succès et avoir un look d'enfer.
Ah et j'ai réussi à perdre pas loin de 30 minutes je pense de façon très conne, simplement parce que cette mécanique de gameplay n'apparait qu'une fois dans tout le jeu et n'est pas expliquée en plus de ressembler à un autre mécanisme fonctionnant différemment... Bref, si vous faites le jeu, quand vous serez dans la pièce avec des maisons qui s'empilent, [spoiler]en plus de pouvoir tirer le mécanisme vers vous, vous pouvez l'orienter à gauche ou à droite..[/spoiler].

8315750.review:
Ico-esque adventure game where your companion is [very explicitly] a big, hulking metaphor for the game creator's abusive, alcoholic father. Subtle this game was not ... but it *was* unique, and in the end it did have a real effect on me. I'm very glad to have played it, but it's heavy enough that I'm unlikely to play through it again.

Strengths: Really striking and original visuals / artistic direction, superb music, refreshing protagonist [the opposite of the powerfulwhitemale we so often see in games]. Short length, ~3.5 hours [a big plus given my schedule].

Weaknesses: The gameplay itself is a bit repetitive [though the constant introduction of new visuals and mechanics does liven things up]. The puzzles are trivial [this is an adventure game, not a puzzle game]. Some minor control+camera wonkiness. Complete lack of subtlety in hitting you with the game's central metaphor [this game's creator is making a very personal, cathartic game.]

Papo & Yo es un juego increíble como pocos.
Aprovechando una mecánica amena y más que fluida, Papo & Yo cuenta una historia emotiva, llena de sensaciones y momentos que realmente te ponen la piel de gallina.
Como juego puede ser algo corto quizás, pero creo que en cuanto a narración y experiencia tiene una duración más que suficiente.

8208564.review:
Plataforma: Steam Windows 8.1
Hard: i3770k + 16GB + ATI 7870
Precio de compra a 13/12/13: 1 key 3 ref (±2.40€)

Juego indie multiplataforma, presentado originalmente para Playstation Network en 2012. De corto desarrollo, menos de 3 horas, nos pone en la piel de Quico, un niño de las favelas. A lo largo de la aventura interactuaremos con Monster, Alejandra y Lula. 

Técnicamente es un juego notable, utiliza el motor 3D Unreal. El diseño de personajes y escenarios es preciosista, con gran detalle, y las texturas empleadas son de gran calidad. Hay una textura con un símbolo al final del juego que destaca entre todas las demás por la cutrez a toda pantalla, pero si bien no hace que desluzca el conjunto total, hace pensar en por qué en ese punto en concreto se ha usado esta textura de baja resolución. Es un detalle tonto, pero que ahí queda.

En el juego aparecen obras reales de conocidos artistas de graffiti (sic), y la verdad es que son coloridos, bonitos y adecuados a la historia. La iluminación es dinámica, y sombras, efectos, nieblas,... resultan apropiadas a la dinámica de juego. La paleta de color es muy cálida, y realmente bonita.

El sonido es correcto, no de notable, le harían falta más samples para los diferentes materiales. 

Lo que destaca enormemente sobre el resto, y está en un nivel superior al de muchas producciones de mucho más dinero, es la banda sonora de Brian D’Oliveira y La Hacienda Creative. Excelente en todos los aspectos. Preciosa, dinámica, se ajusta como un guante a lo que vemos en pantalla y orquestada de verdad, nada de sintes y samples. Espectacular, sabiéndolo ahora tendría que haber buscado el pack que incluye la BSO como DLC.

La historia de Quico es realmente emotiva, y está basada en las experiencias infantiles del director creativo Vander Caballero.
Cita: To my mother, brothers and sisters with whom I survived the monster in my father.
 - Vander Caballero 

Alcoholismo, violencia, amor,... visto desde el particular universo de Quico. Un viaje de rescate, de ayuda, de amor filial... y que acaba como acaba. Es una historia dura y que hace empatizar con su protagonista. Todo este universo onírico del protagonista tiene reminiscencias claras a Inception, de Nolan.



El juego tiene algunas cosillas negativas. Primero el sonido, ya comentado antes, al que le falta variedad para estar a la altura de lo visual. 

También, en aras de mantener un diseño sencillo y jugable en los niveles, puzles y acciones de Quico, hay momentos frustrantes, puesto que p.ej. no se agarra a las cornisas, ni trepa sin escaleras, ni pasa por debajo o por encima de cosas que no estén planeadas para ello. Esto convierte a Quico en una especie de Lara Croft torpe, que no es capaz de hacer cosas bien sencillas que resolverían el reto de manera muy fácil. 

Los puzles a los que te enfrentas tampoco suponen un reto muy complicado, y apenas hay que repetir acciones porque está claramente marcado el recorrido. No hay libertad, ni más de una manera de hacer las cosas. No lo veo rejugable a no ser que seas un completista que te gusten obtener el 100% de los logros.



Pero me ha gustado y recomiendo su compra

8135866.review:
Truly a fantastic adventure game! Papo & Yo will not only present you with interesting puzzles and fun gameplay, but also challenge you to look inward to the demons we all battle throughout life (and more importantly the places we go to escape them).

This is a game about a boy named Quico and his seemingly magical action figure Lula, as well as a giant - and normally docile - beast named Monster. As Quico, you will explore various facets of the dream-like favela he escapes to, where the laws of reality itself bend to the whim of one little boy.

The core gameplay focuses on solving environmental puzzles, many of which involve magic chalk-like drawings on the walls and floors of buildings that let you manipulate this strange and beautiful world in a variety of different ways. There is also some light platforming and some interesting mechanics which involve Lula, who straddles your backside like a knapsack and acts as a sort of jetpack that can also carry out some basic commands (such as flipping switches for you at a distance). Monster will also play a big part (no pun intended) in solving a lot of said puzzles and offers his own unique mechanics; when he is asleep his massive gut can be used as a trampoline of sorts and of course that brute strength of his also comes in handy! You have to be careful, however, as Monster also has an unhealthy addiction to poisonous frogs which cause him to burst into flames and go on a rampage!

All in all this is a refreshing take on 3D puzzle-platformers, that also reminds us just how beautiful and robust the Unreal Engine can still be when in the right hands.

8098793.review:
Okay. Papo & Yo.

My first attraction to the game came with its visuals. The bright, colorful design of the favelas instantly caught my attention in a market saturated by grays and sepias. It stood out, it was new, it was charming. I picked it up, played it for a short while, and then set it down for a week. This should not speak poorly for the game but, rather, for my lack of attention. It took a little bit to get started. But when it did get started, oh man. It got started.

I have since finished the game, and I can now safely call it one of the most important games I have ever played. Not because of anything that it does in the gameplay that is new. The gameplay is only ever average, an affair of finding gears to push and plungers to pull. It has its difficulties - the frame rate will sometimes skip for no reason, and the platforming elements feel strange. Quico, the protagonist, has a strange weight to him, making jumping a bit of an unusual effort. The gameplay is the weakest part of this game.

But it is everywhere else that it shines. It can be terribly dazzling when it wants to be, offering a magically real landscape of favelas that twist and turn and defy gravity, and houses that walk on legs made of chalk, and an enormous pink monster with sun-cracked skin and a dangerous addiction to tropical frogs.

And for every wonderful moment there is a counterpoint, a realization that this experience is inspired by Creative Director / Writer Vander Caballero's relationship with his alcoholic father. Later in the game Monster finally gets his hands on one of those irresistable little frogs, and gobbles it up. He is instantly wreathed in red flames, and he turns on you with a stomach-gnashing roar. Poor little Quico suddenly seems very small against the rampaging Monster, very fragile.

The story's focus is on Quico's quest to cure Monster. You go on a journey to find a shaman, aided by a mysterious girl and an endearing toy robot named Lula, and of course Monster. Sometimes things go quite well. Sometimes they go very wrong.

There are moments were Papo & Yo is absolutely childlike in its wonder.There are moments that are dark and threatening. And there are moments where you have to do things that are painful and liberating. This is a game of powerful, startling, painful moments, strung along to lure you deeper into its narrative.

I feel Papo & Yo is best experienced in a single sitting. The puzzles never become inhibitingly difficult, and you can finish it in about 2 - 4 hours. Which, honestly, you should.

If you want to know more, read the reviews put out by Rock Paper Shotgun and the New York Times.

8086625.review:
Papo & Yo is a metaphorical story played out within a child's imaginative mind. Adhering to its theme, the gameplay and puzzles are simple and childlike. The story progresses, driven by the nostalgic innocence of childhood, and ultimately unfolds out into a darker, more mature theme. 

Recommended to those who can appreciate an emotionally engaging storyline, vibrant visuals, and a uniquely magical soundtrack.

Loved this, in terms of gameplay it's very simple there really wasn't anything you could say was challenging there's no penalty for failure, no healthpoints, no real enemies, there's platforming but it's extremely simple. It's quite short, the graphics are nice but they're not spectacular.

On the other hand it has an poignant very well told story though the ending is a little too blatant in that it just flat out states a lot of the subtext. If you were to compare this to any game it'd be Ico (though it has quite a different feel and story to it) and that's got to be reason enough to play it.

8053429.review:
Podría resumir todo esto en dos palabras, ¡Cómpralo ya! pero no creo que sea la idea que muchos queráis oír, ya que esperáis una conclusión algo más detallada del título analizado, y aquí viene.

Sencillamente Papo & Yo es un título como apenas existen en el mercado. Cuenta una historia muy dura de forma sencilla, amena al jugador y de forma que permite, en cierto modo,  empatizar sin haber vivido algo igual. Solo por esto ya es un juego que merece la pena, pues deja a los típicos juegos “grandes” en el banquillo por un rato.

Está claro que no tiene gráficos realistas de última generación, ni tampoco armas con la que disparar, ni un balón con el que chutar a puerta, ni los necesita, ya que tiene muchísimos detalles que hacen de Papo & Yo un juego excepcional.

También se puede ver como punto negativo la duración del juego, pues en unas 4 o 5 horas puedes terminarlo fácilmente, pero si realmente ahí termina tu conexión con el juego, es que no has sabido comprender la historia y todo lo que es capaz de enseñarte. Realmente es un juego que, aún siendo corto, debería permanecer en tu cabeza algo más de tiempo, aportándote conocimiento y comprensión sobre un tema bastante duro. Por lo tanto este supuesto punto negativo quedaría anulado si has jugado bien a Papo & Yo.

¿Cuál es esa historia tan dura que no terminas de desvelar? Pues si no lo estoy diciendo es por algo, y es que es uno de los puntos claves de Papo & Yo, ser capaz de descubrir por uno mismo qué es lo que sucede, pero si queréis una pista, os dejo la frase que Vander Caballero puso, y podréis ver si lo adquirís, al principio del juego.

A mi madre, hermanos y hermana, con quienes sobreviví al monstruo de mi padre

Antes de terminar, si me gustaría avisar a quienes quieran probarlo que no pueden verlo como un Call of Duty más o como un FIFA, es un juego totalmente distinto, con un estilo al cual no estamos nada acostumbrados, pero del que espero salgan muchos más juegos interesantes.

Si podéis, os recomiendo que compréis también la banda sonora, es bastante inspiradora.

Análisis completo en: http://tecnoslave.com/analisis-papo-yo/

三人称視点のパズルアドベンチャー。少年キコは夢の中のような不思議な世界に迷い込み、少女に導かれてやがて巨大な怪物と出会う。普段は温厚でココナッツ好きで居眠りばかりしている怪物とともに旅を続けるが、怪物は毒ガエルを食べると凶暴化し、キコに襲いかかってくる。地形にしかけられた不思議な魔法陣のような仕掛けを使い、おもちゃのロボット・ルラの手を借り、ココナッツやカエルを追う怪物をうまく利用して、少女を追っていく。
パズルと言ってもそれほど難解ではなく、世界観を楽しむゲーム。壁画や不自然に積み上げられた建物などで構成されるとても美しく不思議な世界、奇抜で奇妙なギミック、世界観にマッチしたアコースティックギターメインの音楽、そして次第に明らかになっていく真実の物語。５～６時間程度でクリア出来てしまい少し物足りなさも残るゲームだが、とても印象に残る作品。

7990629.review:
This is an all around stunning game. From the level design, texture quality, and unique animations to sound design to the beautifully crafted narrative of which the game is focused, nothing fails to impress. The gameplay is based around puzzles/platforming in a three-dimensional environment. The gameplay does not present much of a challenge but the controls are solid and intuitive, playing great with gamepad or keyboard/mouse. The music and ambient environmental sounds are immersive and calming, allowing for a stark contrast when the narrative calls for it. The narrative deals with themes of addiction, abuse, and denial through excellent use of imagery and symbolism.
Everything fits together amazingly well in this game. It's rare to find a game that so excellently parses mature themes without resorting to mindless violence. I've been playing games for fifteen years, and I can honestly say this is one of the best. I bought it on sale not knowing what to expect and having beaten it, I gladly would have paid many times over the price for such an experience.

It's beautiful visuals and it's enjoyable soundtraack also add to the experience significantly. However Papo and Yo is also one of the most tedious games I've played, and although it's a mere three hours long, I still found myself bored with the gameplay. The puzzels in the game are not challenging and the most difficult will simply have you running around for a minute or two until you stumble upon the solution. This makes Papo and Yo extremely difficult to recommend. Buy it on sale if you're interested.

7970226.review:
De vez en cuando nos encontramos ejemplos de lo que se puede llegar a transmitir en un videojuego aparte de puro entretenimiento. Papo y Yo es uno de estos ejemplos en los que un tema tan serio y adulto como el maltrato infantil es plasmado en un videojuego con una estética infantil que oculta su temática a primera vista. 

A nivel jugable Papo y Yo se nos presenta como un híbrido entre plataformas y puzles con una jugabilidad sencilla. La mezcla entre puzles y plataformas está bien conseguida aunque la dificultad general es bastante baja, lo que no ayuda a aumentar su duración que es de unas 3-4 horas. Una vez completado se desbloquea la posibilidad de conseguir reunir unos sombreros ocultos a lo largo del juego, lo que le da rejugabilidad al igual que el conseguir los logros de Steam de los que dispone.

A nivel artístico es simplemente magnífico en todos los aspectos. El diseño de los escenarios, la ambientación y la sublime banda sonora nos acompañan durante toda la historia para sumirnos más profundamente en la experiencia que supone viajar por el mundo de Papo y Yo.

A nivel técnico hay que decir que visualmente se ve bastante bien teniendo en cuenta su naturaleza de carácter independiente. La optimización quizás se podría haber pulido más para ayudar a los equipos más modestos a moverlo con más soltura. El motor de colisiones tampoco funciona perfectamente favoreciendo que en ocasiones nuestro personaje o nuestro acompañante pueda quedarse atascado.

Pros:
- Historia con una temática compleja tratada de modo soberbio.
- Artísticamente bello.
- Banda sonora sublime.

Contras:
- Pocos puzles y sencillos.
- Algunas fases de juego bastante lineales y guiadas.
- La duración en general no es mucha.

Conclusión:
Papo y yo, más que un videojuego al uso es una experiencia jugable. La jugabilidad, si bien es correcta y por momentos interesante, no es lo más importante, si no las sensaciones que nos puede transmitir mientras recorremos su universo. Si te gustan las experiencias únicas e irrepetibles deberías probarlo y si te lo encuentras en oferta ni lo dudes.

Puntuación: 7/10

7965154.review: Good stuff. Graphics are beautiful for an indie, love the music and the story is very touching. It isn't very long and is more about story/presentation than challenge, but it works.

7962368.review: Papo & Yo is a masterpiece. It contains one of the best storytelling I've ever experienced in a video game and it does so in a very unique manner. The game tells the story about a boy and his alcoholic dad and if I understood correctly, you play in Rico's (the boy) mind and you play around with his imagination. The dialogue is pretty much non existent, it's the actual progression through the game that counts. The game features an amazing and wonderful soundtrack that really got me in the right mood while I was playing. Now, most of the gameplay is actually jumping and solving puzzles and even though I usually hate solving puzzles, I was astonished by how simple, but yet, how unique and how clever the puzzles in Papo & Yo were designed. The game has it's touching and very emotional moments and I think that's one of the strongest points of it along with the gorgeous graphics it has. I honestly don't know how can I recommend it more or if I'm recommending it enough. Please, buy it and play it I guarantee you won't regret it.

I applaud the devs for making this game. It's such a personal story with hard subject matters that a few would dare to attempt.
This is a game that's driven on pure emotion. Unfortunately the gameplay suffers a bit for that. You can really feel the terror, but it's just not executed smooth enough. Some of the puzzles were tedious and frustrating. And Monster's AI seems a bit spotty at times, making me reload some previous checkpoints.

The game is beautiful, even though it's set in dirty favela surroundings. The ending especially brings the art to its full potential. The game also gets quite inventive and imaginative at times - due to it being shown in the perspective of a child.

I'll recommend this game, but with a word of caution: most of the game is pretty tedious and slow-paced, but the setting and the conclusion ultimately make this worth it. Buy it from a sale if you can.

On first sight, Papo & Yo could be made for a younger audience. And if you'd leave the story-elements aside, Papo & Yo would be just that. The Gameplay is simple, the mechanics are easy and it is no challenge to beat the game. But Papo & Yo doesn't try to be challenging, it tries to tell a story. The story of a boy who escapes into his own imagination to seek shelter from his alcoholic father, the "monster" if you will. And in his imagination, still, he tries to "heal" the monster from its addiction to frogs.
Papo & Yo tells this story in a metaphorical but so profound way, sometimes you just need to turn off the game and think about what just happened. As a game Papo & Yo is nothing special, but as a tool to express a story it is unique. 

8.5/10

PS: The Soundtrack is superb. I bought this game without the Soundtrack and after playing trough Papo & Yo I feel pretty bad about it.

7926416.review:
This game is a masterpiece! It's the only game I've ever played that left tears in my eyes. Highly personal, and very fun, Papo and Yo is a game about a boy trying to cope with his abusive father. This game opens wounds, but not in a bad way. Instead of determining to make a statement, and pointing it out to you, Papo and Yo immerses you into the story, letting you dictate how you feel about the situations presented. 

The gameplay is puzzle based. It's inventive and very imaginative, but not difficult. Do not expect to burnout your brain trying to solve the puzzles. This game is more about the storyline and your personal reaction to it. Your first play through will probably be 2 - 3 hours; so it's not a bad game to play on a lazy afternoon. The graphics are done well with a rich color palette and tones to make you feel you are in the slums. The voice acting is spot on. 

I know I'm lavishing over this game, but I really can't say enough good things about it. If there was ever a game I wished everyone would play at least once, it would be Papo and Yo!

7919440.review:
First, I'll say that I enjoy games with immersive atmosphere, story, and a unique artistic vision.  Papo & Yo manages to get all three of those to work together to create a truly unique experience.

Above all else, I would call Papo & Yo a 3D adventure game, and the puzzles are worked into the environment in a way that makes them engaging though not the most innovative in the genre.  That's ok, however, because the real star of this game is the immersive experience of wandering through this fantastical favela, appreciating the colorful artwork, and dissecting the meaning and symbolism behind it all.

I don't know if my interpretation behind some of the imagery was intended by the developers, but when a video game can rise to the level of having multiple interpretations, you know it's something special!  The shift from colorful and sunny to drab and rainy...  The graffiti so intentionally placed in each scene...  The act of moving great buildings and how it relates to both boyhood imagination as well as the main character's role in his troubled father's life...

I experienced no bugs.  The visuals are stunning when using the highest graphical settings.  Look around, pause and enjoy the music, and take it in slowly to make the experience last.

The little gems of creativity, the perfect soundtrack, a story unheard of in the game industry, and the sense of wonder you feel as you explore this world simply cannot be missed by any gamer who believes that games can be art.

Un p'tit bijou. Vive les indés.
Entre deux kills, deux tours de pistes ou deux instances, ce p'tit jeu apporte une bouffée d'air frais qui fait un bien fou.

Ceux qui s'attardent sur les graphismes ou la synchro des lèvres peuvent retourner fragger tranquille en 4K, 3D & co.

C'est un jeu de puzzle relativement simple et pour cause il y a une volonté de s'adresser au plus petits. 
Vu les thématiques de l'histoire ... 

+ Décors dépaysants
+ Musique
+ Histoire/Thême
+ Intéractions avec le décor (simple mais toujours sympa)

- Quelques chevauchements de décors ou erreurs de paths/blocage (1 fois en 3 parties). Rien de bien méchant. Je connais plein de jeux AAA, où le personnage ne sait toujours pas monter correctement une échelle sans un ... dans le fondement. A côté de ça, P&Y paraît fluide, à défaut d'avoir 15468416 polygones ;o)

On s'attache et c'est déjà la fin ! Snif.
A vivre une fois selon moi.

7886594.review:
Gameplay: 9/10
Storyline: 9/10
Graphics: 8/10
SoundTrack: 9/10
Overall: 8.75/10


The game puts players in the shoes of Quico, a boy whose complex fantasies are loosely tied with the real world.  Think the dilapidated, South American version of the Hundred Acre Woods.  Quico is looking for a way to cure his monster friend, as every time he eats poison frogs[spoiler](alcohol)[/spoiler], he goes on a rampage, destroying all in his path.  Otherwise, the monster is a peaceful being, and even saves your skin if you mess up in certain puzzles.  At its core, Papo & Yo has a metaphorical, psuedo-autobiographical story that was inspired by the childhood experiences of Minority’s creative director, Vander Caballero.

The two words I'd use to describe this game would be: unsettingly beautiful. What You get in this title is about 3.5 hour of gameplay, which may not seem much, but it's one of those cases where what matters is quality over quantity. And the quality is spectacular, mainly because 'Papo & Yo' comes close to perfection in terms of merging beutifuly designed world, deep plot, and amusing gameplay relying on solving not-so-hard, yet satysfyingly clever puzzles.

Chosing one from points mentioned above it's definitely the plot, and how it's told, that makes 'Papo & Yo' unique experience worth getting. The plot in which we guide Quico through dreamy land strongly resembling one of the south american favelas takes some sudden turn, as we experience more and more deeply methaphorical events culminating in one of the most touching story climaxes I've experienced.

I strongly encourage everyone to give this game a try, I believe none of You will regreat this.

7852324.review:
Perhaps the most emotionally powerful game I've played. Those of you who have read about the game or watched one of the trailers know what the game is about already, but if you haven't, the game is full of metaphors that become clear by the end of the story, and it's devastating.

The gameplay itself is wonderful - it's a puzzle platformer, with some neat puzzle mechanics (changing the world to complete your objectives), with one bit right out of "Inception." The puzzles aren't too difficult, and there is even a hint box in every level in case you need a hint. The art direction is terrific (with street art commissioned from actual artists); combined with the music and sound design, it really immerses you in a favela like nothing else.

If you are looking for a well-told story that immerses you in the world of a young boy in a Brazilian slum dealing with a monster - I can't recommend this enough.

7758556.review: Gorgeous, brilliant, intelligent, beautiful, surreal, magical. A treat for the eyes, the heart and the mind. This indie game cleverly mixes metaphor with gameplay in an amazing, colorful presentation. The puzzles themselves are not too challenging, but still provide a comfortable feeling of accomplishment when you conquer them. The platforming could have used a tiny bit of tweaking though. But the game's real goal is to let you share the emotional journey of the silent protagonist. Unfortunately, as the entire game is a metaphor I don't want to explain it too much by giving away the meaning (sadly the trailers, while beautifully made, blatantly tell the hidden meaning so I recommend to interested parties that they do /not/ watch them). Still, it's hard not to emphasize with the pint-sized hero as he explore his magical world even knowing what is coming. Definitely one of the most interesting games I've played this year.

7667974.review: Quico’s best friend, Monster, is a huge beast with razor-sharp teeth, but that doesn’t scare Quico away from playing with him. That said, Monster does have a very dangerous problem: an addiction to poisonous frogs. The minute he sees one hop by, he’ll scarf it down and fly into a violent, frog-induced rage where no one, including Quico, is safe. And yet, Quico loves his Monster and wants to save him. As Quico, players will build their friendship with Monster by solving puzzles together and adventuring through a magical, surrealist world. Players will need to learn to use Monster’s emotions, both good and bad, to their advantage if they want to complete their search for a cure and save their pal.

7302978.review:
Papo & Yo is a quiet game , but it's telling a story contains lots of strong emotions and deep feelings , it needs us to pay a little bit attention to listen and find out .
 
In the begining , everything looked so peaceful , brought me some kind of calmness . As I was going deeper , I couldn't help realizing that Quico has been bearing a lot , that he must protect the ones he loves , help the one who hurts him......that I must help Quico to fix all of this . I think this is the main reason I continued playing . 

We all make mistakes , grown-up might have a childish immature heart , doing irrational things that only hurt oneself and others , while a little one might have the strongest soul . It doesn't matter how much time that one has been living , what matters the most is that we have the ability to help each other . 

So I thought the game is about saving an angry monster , and I believed I'd done so . But in the end , I realized there's something beyond salvation . I played as Quico , had to do the final steps by myself , all the conflicts within was about to explode . When it's done , we might understand something .

Papo & Yo is a beautiful story , and the story has been being told beautifully . The art is gorgeous in it's own way , very bright and colorful , lighting up the dim raining days , along with the music , creating an exotic world that you want to stay and explore , the ending song is very touching . Lots of elements in the game are symbolic , but it isn't hard to understand , instead , finding out the meaning of these elements by continue playing makes the game more fascinating and engaging . 

Another thing I love about this game is the level designs . The puzzles are so brilliant and inspiring , you solving them by interacting with the imaginative environment . These two parts are blending in with each other beautifully , for several times I was just "Wow" . But every time the monster was in madness , the whole world was immersed in red color , it felt really uncomfortable . And I admit I'm scared of the mad monster , when I was being chased , I could hardly see myself because the monster was so big . The game is a little bit short though , It only took me 4.6h to finish , but I didn't find all the hats , it might be a glitch because I couldn't wear any of them . 

Papo and Yo is not a perfect game , but it's beautiful and good enough , I strongly recommend it !!!

4082630.review:
Papo & Yo is the story of a boy who wants to save his friend Monster. On the surface this seems rather silly and simplistic, but it is a metaphor for a very real and heart wrenching tragedy. It is highly uncommon to see real world social issues brought up in games, especially social issues which no one wants to talk about, but Papo & Yo does this beautifully. The core gameplay is a puzzle platformer. The puzzles are quite easy to be honest, and if you get stuck it has a built in help system. The world you are in is very surreal and fantastical (think Salvador Dali), and is set in a bario neighborhood somewhere in South America. The soundtrack in this game is just fantastic as well. You must play this game to the end, or else it will not make much sense.  While this is certainly not the best game I have ever played, it is by far one of the most memorable. Papo & Yo takes about 3-4 hours to complete. 

9/10

Please upvote this review if you found it useful :)

1751340.review: A barely disguised allegory, the game is occasionally overbearing in its message.  The puzzling and platforming is usually just this side of tedious.  Nevertheless I love this game as it's a perfect example of the interactive form being the correct choice for telling a particular story.  Fear, frustration, and the magical beliefs of a child thinking he can change what is through the few options available to him make for a near seamless intertwining of feeling, meaning, and gameplay.  There were times when I refused to do what the game asked of me; other times it gave me chills as I tried to process how I felt about what was happening.  The art and music are glorious.  Well worth the 3 hours it will take to play to completion.

Definately in the "arty" category, though you probably noticed that if you watched *any* of the production materials. It is short, has several interesting puzzle mechanics that aren't repeated, and is generally a really good 3-5 hours. However, it's SUPER heavy handed. It's quite easy to get the gist of the theme in the opening FMV and you'll definately have it at the second inter-chapter sequence, but it doesn't trust the player at all to come to their own conclusions more or less spelling it out with a chalkboard and pointer.
Would have been much better with a dose of subtlety either thoughout the game and then dumping things the way it did at the end as a reveal or vice versa.

Get it on sale.

218659.review:
Papo and Yo is well worth your time.

Very novel, well executed and powerful subject matter. Papo and Yo is the culimination of a son's experiences with his drunken and abusive father.

Dark stuff indeed, but Papo and Yo is very careful not to overplay its theme too hard.

The game felt to me as if it were borrowing from Miyazaki's Spirited Away at times. A young protagonist trying to cope with circumstances far outside their control. Dark at times, but careful to not to burn you out, feeding you just a small piece of the darker story before dropping you back into lighter fantasy.

The game features a lot of thought and consideration for the design of it's puzzles and mechanics. The platform elements are rarely frustrating. And, the game provides many shortcuts as you explore a given level to help you recover from bad jumps.

This game is just a great bit of fun and has great payoff of its theme. Please give this one a play.

6573536.review:
I decided to buy this game after watching behind the scenes of making the soundtrack, I was fascinated by the way they made the live music, but wasn't expecting that much of the gameplay - and I'm pleased to say this game proved me wrong!

The world is beautiful, and just my cup of tea, part fantasy but realistic. I love the imagination that just shows in the game, and the controls are tight, great quality apart from the camera being a bit too close when the monster's chasing you. 

Now on the emotional part  - the creator said himself that it's based on his experience of being abused in his childhood, and while I have not gone through emotional or physical distress like that personally, the way this game showed me these emotions was simply genius. It was gentle, yet it was a completely new emotional for me. That a video game could do that really earned my respect.

All in all, I'd recommend this game though it's short and maybe not your style if you're looking for a challenge, but it's something I cherish and am glad I've played.

Here's a link to the behind the scenes I mentioned above: http://www.desura.com/games/papo-yo/news/the-music-stylings-of-papo-yos-soundtrack

6342934.review:
Beaucoup de gens se demandent si Papo & Yo est un jeu qui vaut l'intérêt. À ces gens là, je répondrai un grand OUI !

Si le gameplay de ce jeu ne casse pas trois pattes à canard (on peut courir, sauter, enclencher des interrupteurs, tirer des leviers et/ou déplacer des objets, etc...), surtout avec la possibilité de "marcher" qui est totalement inutile et handicapante, tout le reste est une montagne de merveilles d'une richesse absolue.


Commençons par le level design : Papo & Yo est un jeu de plate-forme / puzzle. Il s'agit donc de sauter d'un endroit à un autre, d'activer tel levier qui nous ouvrira une nouvelle voie, de revenir sur ses pas pour inverser un mécanisme enclenché précédemment, etc. Rien de bien incroyable. Mais ce level design s'agrémente d'une originalité tout à fait singulière grâce à la présence de deux personnages qui accompagneront le protagoniste (le petit garçon) tout au long de son aventure : Lulla, un petit robot accroché dans son dos, permettant de prolonger les sauts de base sous forme de mini jetpack ou d'activer des interrupteurs à distance, et le "Monstre", suivant la nourriture à la trace, dormant, ou jouant à la balle avec l'enfant. Si ce Monstre paraît doux et gentil tel un immense ours en peluche, il faudra s'en méfier. Qui sait ce qu'il se passera lorsqu'il avalera une grenouille ?

L'ensemble du jeu est basé sur ce lien entre le petit garçon et le monstre. On s'attache à ce colosse, et même lorsqu'il entre en furie, il ne peut que blesser notre personnage. Car dans Papo & Yo, il est "impossible" de mourir. Comme dans tout bon jeu de plate-forme il y a des gouffres sans fin, ou des étendues d'eau mortelles, mais tomber dedans n'entraîne qu'une réapparition à un endroit plus sûr.


Pour agrémenter ce petit résumé, je pourrais parler des graphismes plutôt bons pour un jeu indé, du character design simple mais parfaitement efficace et parlant, de la musique en symbiose avec le déroulement, etc... Tant d'éléments servant à ancrer le joueur dans un univers extrêmement personnel pour le créateur. Et c'est bien là la force du jeu : son créateur y raconte sa vie et nous invite à nous mettre dans la peau de l'enfant qu'il a été en vivant ses joies, mais surtout ses souffrances. Car derrière un univers semblant joyeux et coloré se cache un terrible secret. Plus le joueur progresse dans le jeu, plus l'univers devient sombre et se complexifie, jusqu'à la grande révélation finale qui laisse pantois, dévoilant la dure vérité sur la signification de chaque élément et petit détail du jeu.


Finalement, le monde de Papo & Yo nous donne l'impression d'être dans un film tel qu'Inception. Car plus qu'un simple jeu, il s'agit d'une narration dans laquelle nous sommes bien plus spectateur que joueur. Les très rares dialogues sont presques superflus, le game design se suffisant à lui-même. Nous agissons sur les rêves d'un petit garçon qui crée un univers avec son quotidien : un monde de bidonville que l'on transforme au gré de son imagination. Ce jeu est donc réservé aux personnes souhaitant voyager et découvrir un univers unique, fruit d'une mise en scène autobiographique somptueusement menée. Le seul défaut que l'on pourrait trouver à Papo & Yo est sa courte durée de vie, même si personnellement je la trouve quasi parfaite par raport à l'essence narrative de ce jeu.

En définitive, Papo & Yo est une pure merveille que je classe sans hésiter dans mon top 10 des meilleurs jeux de tous les temps (à la date où j'écris cet article). Attention : si vous êtes sensibles, ce jeu raconte une histoire vraie, et comme beaucoup d'histoire vraie, elle est pleine de souffrance et de tristesse, alors préparez les mouchoirs ! Et pour ceux qui veulent en rajouter une couche, je conseille le film Max et les maximonstres, présentant des similitudes frappantes avec Papo & Yo.

1692890.review:
This is definitely one of those cases of "games as art". While it's a pretty standard puzzle platformer, Papo & Yo is dealling with some pretty interesting concepts. The setting is some sort of South American chanty town outside of reality, and the main character has to navigate the world by manipulating the landscape, and through the assistance of his little robot friend Lula, as well as a large placid creature called Monster.

The "arty" aspect comes to play when trying to use Monster to get to new places. Monster has three priorities, sleeping, eating coconuts and eating frogs. You can wake him up and lure him to places you need him using coconuts, but you want to keep him away from frogs. If he eats a frog he'll start rampaging and only care about eating more frogs and hurting you. This fact comes to play in the plot with various cut scenes that show there's more going on than it seems.

The puzzles are fun, the art style is pretty (I quite liked the landscape manipulation effects), the music is atmospheric and has an odd nostalgic quality to it, and the plotline is engaging. My only gripe is that it's a bit on the short side and a little too simple. Oh, I also wish the dedication made at the start of the game was made at the end of the game instead, and it was a little more subtle with its "plot twist". All in all I enjoyed the experience though, and feel it was a successful "arty" game that still managed to be fun.

I strongly suggest avoiding trailers if you plan on playing it, so you can avoid spoilers.

658426.review:
An adventure/puzzle-platformer that's light on challenge but heavy on quality story-telling. Excellent presentation and beautiful Latin American-themed artwork/music make Papo & Yo both a visual and audible pleasure. While the puzzles aren't anything that'll test your mind, it's less about figuring out how to solve them and more about watching and admiring the solutions as they unfold. The way you can manipulate the world with the push or pull of a lever is a neat sight to behold and has a "child-like imagination" feel to it. There are a few technical issues present (noticeable framerate drops here and there), but nothing significant.

Overall, an impressive game that does a great job of using metaphors and symbolism to tell a powerful story full of dark subject matter in an accessible manner. Short, but still well worth playing.

2494245.review: Yes, its another one of those artsy Indie titles but this one comes frighteningly close to achieving its vision. The games plot is simple but engaging: the main character is a little boy on a quest to cure his companion, a giant pink "monster" who is friendly, helpful, even nurturing and fun-loving at times but becomes violent, angry and...abusive upon consuming a frog. The whole setup actually is one huge metaphor for the story of the Creative Director's father and his alcoholism problem. With its surreal and colorful art style and its uplifting music, the game creates a facade of juvenile fun, but if the metaphor is to be taken seriously, the entire ending act of the boy's 'quest' might well be the most disturbing thing ever put into such a deceptively jovial piece of work. The only blemish on this game's artistic vision are the collectible hats, unlocked only on a second playthrough. But the simple but elegant puzzles and the great story closure make it such that a second playthrough can only cheapen the experience. Ironic, given that the collectibles were there to increase its value-for-money given its high pice tag and short playtime.

突拍子もない非現実世界かと思いきや、実は…というタイプのゲーム。
気軽に遊べる一方で、扱っているテーマ自体はとても重かったりする。
音楽がとても素晴らしい。あとモンスターが思いの外かわいい。

ゲーム難易度に変化をつける手段をもう幾つか設計していれば、
きっと評価はもっと上がっていたと思われる。それに加えて、
マップ内の進行ルートをマルチ化して、エンディングも分岐させていれば
スコア8.4～8.7ぐらいは狙えた気がする。

しっかり作られたセンスを感じるゲームですが、2度楽しむのは難しい。
それを考慮すると5ドルぐらいの時ならば損はしないゲームだと思います。

3543586.review:
"Ba ha ha video games can't deal with any sort of real-world issues!"
"Yeah?  How about THIS!"
"Oh no I am undone!  HSSSSSS!"

Papo & Yo is an extremely metaphorical game about a boy's relationship with his abusive, alcoholic father (I don't think that's really a spoiler, considering the trailer makes that fairly obvious), and it's based on the lead designer's own childhood experiences.  The game deals with the issue absolutely brilliantly.  It really perfectly conveys the mixture of love, fear, and pity Quico feels.  It's also a fantastic example of gameplay-story integration, one of the best I've played.  The gameplay of alternating between working with and running from Monster really makes you feel the themes, which wouldn't work in any other medium.  To top it off, the gameplay is actually quite fun, and the graphics and music are both gorgeous.  If you value games as a storytelling medium, play Papo & Yo.

4732648.review: The graphics aren't groundbreaking (although they are beautiful) and there are some collision issues and places I got my character (physically) stuck. That being said, the story this game tells is heart wrenching! You start off chasing a mysterious girl who can seemingly create doors and portals out of thin air. To chase her, you complete some easy puzzles with your robot friend (who hangs on your back and assists you in opening areas that you can't reach). Shortly after, you meet a large pink monster who helps you out in completing some more puzzles. That's when you start getting glimpses of places and things (in what seems like another universe), and you realise that everything you do just might be a metaphor for something that has happened to you. You can manipulate the world and it's objects by moving gears and cranks that are shining with an other-worldly glow. A few times my mind went "whaaaa?", but I still had lots of fun. The music was beautifully composed, and near the very end, it was bringing out so many emotions as the music (and story) unraveled. Even though it was only about 3-3.5 hours to play through, I think it was the perfect length to tell the story it needed to tell.

Papo & Yo is a story about a troubled childhood and using infinite imagination to escape, rationalize, endure... and, in the end,  let go of the troubled memories.
 
The story is presented in a spectacular and beautiful world, with impressive visuals and weird adventure-like puzzle design. 

The entire game world is a metaphor, every element having real meaning- some things quite obviously so, while others are left for interpretation and discussion.

The game is neither long nor hard, but keeps throwing one impressive scene after another to constantly occupy the player's attention.

While it might not be everyone's cup of tea, I was definitely impressed and had to keep playing until I finished the story in one sitting. Take that as a recommendation if you wish :)

397576.review:
It's a surprisingly affecting story. The monster, Papo, is a metaphor for the alcoholic father of the game's director. But what could have easily been a preachy mess turns out to be an engaging puzzle game with a poignant story. The Brazilian favela makes for an interesting setting, the music is lovely, and the ending actually chocked me up. The only downside is that it's quite short, only about 3-4 hours, but I ended up playing it a second time just because I enjoyed the world and characters so much. Highly recommended.

[UPDATE] I just nominated Papo & Yo for the “I'm Not Crying, There's Something In My Eye” Award in this year's Steam Awards. It was a tough choice between this, Gone Home, and Valiant Hearts; but there is something special about Papo & Yo. It touches on a subject that has affected me personally, so it ultimately got my vote. I hope you'll consider it, too.

3800749.review:
Papo & Yo ('Father & I') is a third person puzzle platformer and tells the story of Quico and his friend Monster, who has a prefernce for tasty frogs. Unfortunately, these frogs turn the calm Monster into a violent and dangerous creature, so Quico sets out to find a cure for his friend - but is there any?

While this sounds like your average game story, it gains a lot of emotion and intensity once you realize that the story is metaphorical for Creative Director Vander Caballero's troubled childhood. It's relatively subtly tied into the game and if you don't pay enough attention or don't care about it, you could very well miss the message of the game, so don't rush it, step back for a moment and let the impressions work.

The game has relatively simple platforming mechanics and you will mostly end up jumping over gaps to progress in the level. Due the general pace of the game, there hardly are any timed events where, for example, you have to press a button and then quickly run somewhere to move on.

Relatively early into the game you also find your friend Lula, a toy robot who will latch onto your back and lets you double jump by launching his tiny jet pack. Additionally, you can also command him to flip switches that are out of your reach.

While the puzzles present themselves in a unique and creative manner, they aren't really challenging at all and mostly just require simple combination skills. It's a shame because the puzzle design as such is wonderful and could've made for some fun challenges.

Papo & Yo is based on the Unreal 3 Engine and while this engine isn't exactly the standard for visual fidelity these days, the game still looks pretty good and the lighting and level design add a lot to the overall atmosphere.

With roughly 4 hours of playtime, the game is fairly short, but if the game would've been filled with repetative puzzles in favor of playtime, the emotion and strength of the story would have suffered immensively and would've made this game just yet another average puzzle platformer.

There are dolls scattered throughout the levels and once you beat the game, those dolls will receive hats which you then can collect in a second playthrough. Other than that, the game doesn't provide you with anything else to do, which is fine - games like Papo & Yo aren't meant to be played for days, weeks or months. They want you to immerse yourself for a few hours, tell you a story and maybe even think about it a few days later.

Papo & Yo is a prime example of how emotional and intense video games can be. Don't buy it for the platforming and don't buy it for the puzzles. Buy it for the story and let the emotions take over.

3625032.review:
Papo & Yo is a moving, courageous game. The first thing that struck me about the game was the beautiful and changing landscape of the South American favela that is Quico's playground. The game mechanics center around manipulating this setting in unexpected but mostly intuitive ways. The puzzles are not terribly challenging, but they're also not so easy that they become boring or tedious.

The real charm and heart of Papo & Yo is the story and the relationships between Quico, Lula, Alejandra, and Monster. It's quite a short game, and the overarching metaphor is only thinly veiled, but the conclusion still left me stunned (and in need of an entire box of tissues). Papo & Yo is an example of how games have the power to do more than simply entertain.

671587.review:
This is an odd game to recommend because to explain what it is is to spoil it a bit.

Basically it is a puzzle game and a short one at that; it took me about 3 and a half hours to complete it one time. Personally I'm glad I played it but if I hadn't got it on sale for £8 my view might be different. 

It's a very refreshing game, making a point while giving you some really cool puzzles. it tries to engage you in the 'story' and, for me, did this quite nicely with subtle metaphors and imagery. Different people will experience this game differently, if you want a game that is just about the action or puzzles, this might disappoint, but I found it to be an incredibly chilled out game, you can't die and the music is very well done, fitting the atmosphere without becoming repetative. The graphics on the trailer look really poor, but I was surprised by how nice it looked.

When I finished the game I felt like it could have been longer with more puzzles, but at the same time, I played it through in one night and it was a cool little game that kept me entertained start to finish. In some ways, the fact that it's short makes it more enjoyable.

If you can get it on sale then I recommend it, it's very different and if you can think of it loosely like paying for a film, in this case a puzzle 'experience', then it's well worth £8.

2454339.review: My god. This game dredged up memories of a time when I had to let go of a best friend of mine because of illegal drug use. It was alcohol specifically, that made me decide. In the moment when he broke into a liquor cabinet and began to get drunk, (while of course being underage.), I was afraid. I let him get drunker and drunker, and when he was stumbling around and falling down, I got in my car, (which had his stuff and the stuff of the people who were with us.) , and I left and drove to his parents house. I deposited everyone's stuff on the front porch and rang the doorbell and told his dad where he was and what he was doing. Afterwords, I never looked back. I haven't seen him in years now, nor do I want to, but I just know, if I saw him again I could become friends again with him easily. But I took the harder route of not forgiving him and simply letting him go. The ending of Papo and Yo was a metaphor for an actual moment in my life, and it was one of , if not THE most, moving ending to a video game I have ever seen. Millage may vary for other people, but at least for me, I felt very moved. It was just like revisiting that moment again, but this time, I was able to let go more easily. This is a game that simply must be played. It is a beautiful piece of art.

811601.review:
Papo & Yo is a puzzle platformer that's light on the puzzles but heavy on the virtual button/lever pushing/pulling. The story is impressive for a puzzle game, though. No shallow stories here, this one actually has depth, giving the player indications on what might have happened in the past, leading to the events in this game.

The graphics are acceptable. They're nothing special but not terrible either. At least they're colorful, and fit the environments you'll come across. 

The music and voice acting (gibberish ?) are done very well, by the way.

Papo & Yo is a short game which you'll complete it in 3 hours. After that you can play the game again collecting hats, but to be honest that's not really incentive enough to play it again. Unless you're a fanatic of course.

An ok game that's currently too pricey for what you get. The perfect price point for this game would be €7-8 or less. Your choice.

[Rating: 76/100]

D'autre part si on se laisse porter par l'ambiance, Papo & Yo est une ballade dans l'univers onirique d'un enfant dans les favelas de Rio, certes l'histoire est extrêmement dur puisqu'il aborde l’alcoolisme et la maltraitance, mais il s'agit avant tout du voyage initiatique de Quico. Le jeu est tres court, à peine 3 heures, mais si vous avez fait l'effort de vous plonger dans cette univers, l'histoire vous touchera. Soyez bien conscient en achetant Papo & Yo qu'il ne se s'agit pas d'un jeu, mais d'une oeuvre artistique.

6514992.review:
몽환적인 분위기. 아름다운 배경과 그래픽. 기발한 상상력과 적절한 난이도의 퍼즐. 그뒤로 흐르는 아름다운 BGM. 그리고 동화같은 이야기속에 숨겨진 현실의 암울한 진실까지. 

 인디게임 중에선 가히 완벽하다고 칭하고 싶을 만큼 게임이다. 게임성으로 따지면 분위기는 림보를 능가하고, 상상력은 브릿지와 맞먹는다. 
 보통 퍼즐류 게임은 도저히 내머리로는 풀 수 없는 부분이 한두군데씩은 꼭 있어 공략이 거의 필수다시피 한데 이 게임은 그렇지 않다. 적절한 난이도로 인해 나와 같은 라이트게이머들도 부담없이 즐길 수 있고, 퍼즐로 인해 머리를 싸매지 않아도 되니 게임에 더 녹아들 수 있게 한다.
 한국어는 지원되지 않지만 대사도 별로 안나오고 초등 저학년 수준의 영어 실력만 되면 충분히 스토리를 이해 할 수 있다. 제작자가 어릴때 아동학대의 피해자여서 자신의 어릴적 경험을 동화처럼 풀어냈다고 한다. 얼핏 보면 그냥 퍼즐만 푸는 몬스터와 꼬마 이야기 같지만 그 속에 담겨있는 진실들은 현재에도 크게 화두되고 있는 문제이다. 더 자세한건 스포일러이니 더이상 다루지는 않겠다. 
 덤으로 그래픽은 최상까지는 아니지만 배경이 참 아름답다. 게임에 더욱 몰입하게 해주는 요소이다. BGM역시 잔잔하게, 남미 특유의 느낌이 물씬 풍기게 게임 뒤로 흐른다.

 정말 내 인생에서 꼭 한번 추천하고픈 게임이다. 나는 시험을 일주일 앞두고 이틀만에 엔딩까지 다 봐버렸다. 하지만 그 시간이 후회되지는 않는다. 이 게임에 대해 그만큼의 가치를 느끼고 생각할수 있었으니까. 시험이야 남은 시간동안 조금 더 열심히 하면 될것을.

610082.review:
I played this on PS3 a few months ago, and the devs gave me a free key to test 3d support for them.

It's essentially a puzzle-platformer, but to distil it down to its base gameplay elements is to do it a disservice. It's a really affecting story, about a real person's experiences dealing with an abusive parent. That's not something you see very often, and it's a really special experience. The gameplay doesn't always hold up as well as the story - most of the puzzles are reasonably easy, and don't always do as much as they could to establish the characters. But for the most part, it's very well done. An experience well worth having. 

The following is all to do with stereo 3d support.

In terms of 3d, this game works really well with only a few minor problems. Probably less than 10 broken shaders in the whole game. You get great toyification effect with the depth and convergence tweaked, and while there are a few issues, they are all pretty minor and easily fixed. Convergence may seem locked at first, but you just need to hold the button down for 20s or so. Hopefully we can see some developer support on the couple of minor issues left. The problems are as follows:

Shadows must be set to low or very low. They do not render correctly on higher settings. Low setting gives "blob" shadows, very low turns them off. There is a brief cutscene fairly early on where you first become aware of Monster by seeing his shadow as he walks above you. Having shadows off kinda ruins that, but it's not a big issue anywhere else.

Interface elements (prompts and speech bubbles) render at screen-depth. This isn't much of a problem, as there is no hud, speech is rare, and so are prompts.

World detail must be set to medium. Anything higher and the depth-of field or fog effects cause serious halos. Not sure which effect is causing it, but medium and below disable it with no other noticeable quality loss.

When Monster is in "angry" mode, his flames render differently for each eye, causing a flickering effect. Barely noticeable.

Water shader has massive halos. Fortunately this game doesn't have much water.

51045.review: An amazing and "fantastic" adventure, filled with deeper emotions and a mysterious story line. Even though there is almost no talking in this game, it is yet filled with a sense of mystery and darkness. Wondering what story is truly behind this game, it will make you want to finish the game even faster. This game will intrigue even the youngest as the oldest audience of gamers. It is certainly worth the time and money to try this game out. It is a beautiful and well made game.
